item.title: Kryxis
item.description:
Kryxis is a primordial entity of pure nothingness, an embodiment of the void that existed before creation. It was not crafted by the Five Gods but born from the empty spaces left untouched in their grand design. Unlike the gods, who shaped and wove existence into the Celestial Tapestry, Kryxis was never given a place, and its very essence was antithetical to creation. Unmaking: Everything Kryxis touches begins to unravel, as its nature is to consume and return all things to void. It does not destroy in the conventional sense—it erases, making it as though something never existed. The Hunger: Kryxis craves a place in existence, but its very being is paradoxical—it cannot create, only consume. This hunger drives it to expand endlessly, devouring reality to make space for itself. Wraithborn: The corruption Kryxis spread during its brief presence in the Tapestry gave birth to the Wraithborn, shadowy entities of despair and emptiness that still haunt the world.
Shadowmarked: Mortals who were exposed to its power became the first Shadowmarked, inheriting a connection to the void that grants them dark powers but tempts them toward oblivion. When Destiny gave Kryxis a single void-thread in the Celestial Tapestry, the Voidbringer failed to contain its hunger and instead began consuming creation itself. This led to a war between the gods and Kryxis, where even divine might struggled against the endless void.
In the final battle, Destiny sacrificed his place among the heavens to weave an unbreakable seal, banishing Kryxis to the Endless Expanse, a realm beyond time and space where its hunger could do no harm. Though Kryxis is imprisoned, its influence lingers in the scars left on the world—dark patches in the sky where stars refuse to shine, and the restless stirrings of the Wraithborn.
Kryxis remains a cosmic horror, an ever-hungry force beyond reality, waiting for the slightest weakness in its prison. Some cultists and warlocks seek to commune with the Voidbringer, believing that through its power, they might reshape reality—or unmake it entirely. Though the gods sealed it away, whispers of the void still echo in the forgotten corners of Fiondell, a reminder that even creation is not immune to the nothingness from which it came.

item.title: The Founding of the Church of the Five
item.description:
As recorded by Known "To see is not merely to witness. It is to understand. And I have seen much."
In the age when the stars had yet to dim and angels still graced the lands openly, I was sent from the celestial spires by Fionil, my eternal guide and the Keeper of Order. The world then was loud with mortal doubt and quiet with faith. But one voice, soft yet persistent, rose amid the din — a man whose curiosity had not yet been dulled by the cynicism of his kind. His name was Eldrin.I watched him for many seasons. He did not pray in temples, for there were none. He did not seek miracles, for he believed they were earned. Instead, he asked questions of the wind, the fire, the roots, and the stars. And they, in their way, whispered back.I came to him upon the Hill of Still Winds — a place where mortals claim the air holds its breath to listen. Fitting, for the moment demanded silence.The light I arrived in was not for grandeur. It was for clarity. When I descended, robes woven from thought and memory cloaked me. I spoke not only aloud, but directly into the root of his being. “Eldrin the Seeker,” I said. “You who ask without demanding, who seek without arrogance — you are heard.” He trembled, and rightly so. To be seen fully is a rare and terrible thing. “I am unworthy,” he whispered, as all who are chosen tend to say. “No,” I replied, “you are curious — and that is enough. The gods have no use for perfection. They seek honesty, doubt, and wonder. You are all three.”
I offered him the first thread of the tapestry to come. A sliver of divine light, coiled like memory in my palm. “Take this. Not as proof, but as purpose. Build not a monument to us — build a space for others to find themselves.” When his hand met mine, I showed him glimpses of what could be. A hall of stained glass and flickering candles. Pilgrims weeping at altars. Laughter and study, debate and silence. The temple was born not of stone, but of vision — a dream planted like a seed in soil that had long awaited the rain.
He returned to his village changed — not glowing or grand, but with purpose in his gait. He spoke of gods not as unreachable forces, but as companions yet unmet. And of me, Known, not as a deity, but as a messenger bearing something deeply mortal: a path.They doubted him, of course. Doubt is a cousin to belief — louder, but less loyal.So we answered again.On the Day of the Veil, the mist rolled in with unnatural grace. The air thickened with time, as if the world held its breath. I did not come alone. Three more stepped into the mortal veil:
Prai, my brother of reverence, whose voice makes stone weep.
Willia, patient and unreadable, her silence more instructive than sermons.
Clock, embodiment of inevitability — time made flesh and ticking. The villagers fell to their knees, some in terror, others in awe. But one woman — Heda, old and wise — stepped forward and asked not if we were gods, but why we had come.
Prai, ever the teacher, answered: “Because you are ready to listen. And the Five are ready to speak.” It was then that the Ritual of Attunement was given — a bridge between the divine and the mortal, carved from trial and sincerity.The rites were never meant to be simple. A god’s favor is not bought with coin or blood, but with transformation.
1. The Rite of Patience — Fionil's Mark Seven days of silence. No food. No comfort. Only stillness. Many failed. But those who endured were gifted with the Everflowing Hourglass, not etched on skin but soul — proof they had touched time without being swept away by it.
2. The Rite of Humility — Flujack’s Mark The peak must be climbed with only a lantern — no tools, no guide. It was not the summit that mattered, but the journey in darkness. The Open Sky mark bloomed on those who reached the top with hearts unburdened by pride.
3. The Rite of Courage — Tellemori’s Mark Into the wild woods they went, to the heart where magic sleeps and madness wakes. They returned changed — with a seed of the earth’s dreaming, and the Rooted Stone etched into their being.
4. The Rite of Compassion — Trill’s Mark Thirty days with the sick, the broken, the forgotten. Not one act of healing, but a month of it — not for recognition, but love. Those who did not grow bitter emerged with the Radiant Hand.
5. The Rite of Resolve — Onigod’s Mark
Their worst fear, made flesh by Poki, our enigmatic sibling. To endure it — not to defeat it — was enough. Those who stood tall bore the Arcane Flame, a mark of resilience and will.I have seen each rite enacted. I have seen failure, tears, joy, and revelation. All of it is worthy.When the Hall of Five Flames stood complete, stone kissed by sweat and sacred intention, two more of our kin came to bear witness.
Livius, ever gentle, placed a blessing upon the people — not with thunder or storm, but with a breeze that smelled of spring. “You have built more than walls,” he told Eldrin. “You have built continuity. Your task is only just begun.”
Then came Destiny — capricious, brilliant, impossible Destiny — leaning against a pillar like a poet late to his own funeral. “Don’t make it too predictable,” he chuckled. “The gods do love a good twist.” And with that, they left, but not truly. We never truly leave.The faithful began to write. To sing. To pray.Each god was honored in their own voice — not demanded by them, but discovered by mortals. I copied their words below, that they may be remembered:
Prayer to Fionil “Timekeeper, guide my path...” — and they were guided.
Prayer to Flujack “Lift me from the shadows...” — and they were lifted.
Prayer to Tellemori “Root me in wisdom...” — and they were steadied.
Prayer to Trill “Grant me the heart to heal...” — and they became healers.
Prayer to Onigod “Shield me from unseen terrors...” — and they stood unfearing.
And they prayed to us, the angels, in their need and wonder. They prayed to Destiny, to Lucina, to Death, to Loki, to Undean — to those who answer when gods are silent. And we listened.Eldrin has long since returned to dust, but his spirit lingers in every question asked beneath a holy roof. The Church lives not because we ordained it, but because mortals chose it.I watched it all. I recorded every moment. “To be remembered is to never truly die,” I once told Eldrin. He smiled. “Then let me live forever in questions.” And so he does.
— Known Archivist Eternal Third Flame of the Five

item.title: The Beginning of All Things
item.description:
In the beginning, there was the Vast Void, an expanse without form or purpose, an endless silence. From this emptiness, the Divine arose—five beings of infinite power and wisdom, destined to craft the fabric of existence. These were the Five Gods of Existence, eternal and boundless: Flujack, Trill, Tellemori, Fionil, and Onigod.Each god bore a sacred mantle, embodying the essential forces that would sustain all creation:
Flujack, Keeper of Air, Sky, and Light, brought clarity and illumination to dispel the darkness.
Trill, Lord of Divinity, Dragons, and Life, was the fountain from which all living souls would spring, entrusted with the sacred cycle of birth and death.
Tellemori, Shaper of Water and Earth, laid the very foundation of existence, molding the seas, lands, and moons.
Fionil, Mistress of Time, Space, and Free Will, ordained the flow of moments and the structure of the cosmos, gifting mortals the power to choose their own paths.
Onigod, Weaver of Arcana and Keeper of Beasts, adorned creation with magic and wonder, her touch giving rise to creatures both majestic and fearsome. Thus, the Five Gods stood as the architects of all things, bound by harmony yet each imbued with their own divine purpose.The Order of CreationAnd so, the gods began their sacred work.
Fionil, the First Mover, reached into the void and wove the threads of time and space. The heavens took shape, and the tapestry of creation stretched across the nothingness. She divided the endless expanse into realms, a stage upon which the other gods would cast their blessings.
Flujack, bearer of radiant light, ignited the first star, and the darkness fled before him. From his breath came the sun to mark the days, the moon to guide the nights, and the celestial spheres to adorn the heavens.
Tellemori, with hands steady and strong, sculpted the earth and seas. He raised mountains that touched the clouds and carved rivers that danced to the oceans. By his will, the moons and stars took their orbits, their movements marking time across the ages.
Trill, giver of life, exhaled the breath of vitality upon the world. He planted forests, set flowers to bloom, and commanded the beasts to rise from the earth and sea. With Fionil, he created the first dragons—creatures of unmatched wisdom and might, guardians of balance.
Lastly, Onigod, the arcane weaver, filled the world with magic. She crafted beasts of wonder and fear, monsters to challenge the strength of mortals, and mysteries to stir their hearts. She ensured that magic, both a gift and a trial, would forever shape the destiny of creation.When their work was done, the Five Gods gazed upon the world they had made, and they declared it good.The Angels of CreationTo maintain the balance of their creation, the Five Gods fashioned divine agents—angels, sacred guardians imbued with their essence.
Fionil, the Mistress of Time, created the first angels to uphold her design:
Clock, to watch over the eternal march of time.
Willia, to guard the freedom of choice.
Known, to grant wisdom to seekers of truth.
Filla, to guide the passions and emotions of all beings.
Destiny, the Hand of Fate, to nudge mortals toward their purpose while preserving their agency.
Trill, the Giver of Life, brought forth angels to tend the cycle of existence:
Livius, who ushered new souls into the world.
Death, who guided spirits to their eternal rest.
Prai, who inspired mortals to honor the divine.
Drana, the defender of dragons and the sacred bloodlines.
Lucina, who chose to govern the planes of darkness, becoming the first Demonlord.
Onigod, the Arcane Weaver, created guardians of magic and the monstrous:
Arcna, who bestowed the gift of magic upon mortals.
Poki, who shepherded the creatures of the wild.
Loki, who delighted in stirring mortal hearts with mischief.
Udean, who presided over the shadowy realms of undeath.
Cupin, who tempted mortals with sin to test their resolve.
Flujack, the Keeper of Light and Sky, appointed his angels to govern the heavens:
Day and Night, who kept the cycle of time.
Sandman, who brought the gift of sleep to weary souls.
Sky, who ruled the winds and storms.
Mr. Season, who wove the ever-changing tapestry of the year.
Tellemori, the Shaper of Nature, gave life to guardians of the wild:
The Lady of Fey, protector of the mystical realms of the fey.
Plantios, who nurtured the growth of flora.
Lady Love, who sowed harmony and affection among mortals.
Thus, the Angels stood as stewards of creation, their hands ever guiding, their presence unseen.The Mortal Races and the Eternal Balance
In their final act of creation, the Five Gods shaped the mortal races—humankind, Elves, Dwarfs, Orc, and Halfling—each a reflection of their divine essence.
To house their souls and guide their destiny, Trill crafted the afterlife:
A realm of blessed peace, the Plane of the Gods, where the virtuous would dwell.
A realm of trial and penance, Damnation, for those who turned from the light.
In Damnation, Lucina, once an angel of light, became the first Demonlord, ensuring that even the wayward would find their path, however harsh.And so, the Five Gods established the eternal design: a world of wonder and challenge, of light and shadow, of freedom and destiny. Their work was perfect, their wisdom eternal, and their love unyielding.

item.title: The Temple of Demre
item.description: The Tapestry is not merely a religion; it is the sacred pattern upon which the entire world rests, a divine weave of lives, fates, and cosmic intentions. Its followers believe every soul is a thread in a grand design spun by the angel Destiny, steward of fate and time’s unknowable pattern.Demre Stade is the beating heart of The Tapestry. Built upon an ancient, enchanted faultline where ley energies cross like woven strands, the city radiates divine resonance. Pilgrims pour into its sacred boulevards from every corner of the continent, seeking blessings, prophecies, or glimpses of the living embodiments of faith — the Pope, the Holy Knights, or even a whisper from the Angels.Massive alabaster walls, inscribed with living scripture, encircle the city. Temples, courts, libraries, and pilgrimage houses form a maze of sacred institutions, all radiating around the Seat of the Twin Threads — a vast marble complex shared by the Pope and Queen.The Temple Knights are not just soldiers. They are judges, priests, paladins, bureaucrats, and prophets. Their armor is ceremonial and blessed, adorned with the crest of interwoven golden threads. They represent the law, the sword, and the will of both Queen of Demre and Pope of the Tapestry. Total Number: ~11 million Based in Demre Stade: ~500,000 Structure: Divine-Military Hybrid, split between Church and Crown The Pope, the highest mortal voice of Destiny, serves as the divine guide. The Queen of Demre, chosen by blood and ceremony, represents mortal governance and order. Together, they are The Twin Threads — seen as the warp and weft of worldly and divine will. The Twin Threads – Pope & Queen of Demre The Pope speaks prophecy and issues holy decrees; the Queen commands the realms and defends the people. Together, they may ordain new Holy Knights. The Eleven Holy Knights – Emissaries of the Divine Each represents a principle thread in The Tapestry (e.g., Valor, Mercy, Judgment, Sacrifice, etc.). They are half-saints, given sacred names upon ascension. They are not merely leaders; they are symbols, legends, and champions all chosen by different angels. The Special Temple Guardians – Destiny’s Fangs A secretive force of 75 warriors chosen directly by Destiny, Archangel of Fate. They are half-seers, half-enforcers, acting on dreams, omens, and divine compulsion. Often Paladins of the Oath of Threads or Warlocks of the Fatebound Chain, they are Destiny’s personal instruments — feared and revered. Some call them the Threadcutters. Temple Commanders – Judges and Strategists Act as magistrates, generals, and interpreters of law. They often reside in regional temples, overseeing large sections of the world. Temple Guardians – Keepers of the Sacred Places These soldiers are stationed at holy sites, libraries, and relic vaults. They are trained not just in warfare but in lore and divine security. Temple Captains – Masters of Legions Each Captain leads a force of 250,000, a massive responsibility requiring logistical, spiritual, and military mastery. Their commands are akin to small kingdoms in their own right. Temple Leaders – Platoon Commanders Leaders of a unit of 100 knights, often selected from among proven warriors and acolytes. They maintain discipline and religious adherence. Temple Priests and Nuns – Spiritual Guides They maintain the rituals of The Tapestry, deliver sermons, and offer thread-readings (divinations of fate). Many are scholars of The Loomscript, the prophetic language of Destiny’s will. Temple Knights – Holy Enforcers The primary soldier-priests of the order. They act as both battlefield warriors and city patrollers. Their weapons are blessed, and their oaths are binding. Temple Watchers – Peacekeepers and Judges of the People These are the common faces of the Temple law. They wear simpler armor, yet their presence holds the force of divine mandate. They record all crimes in Threadbooks, which are said to be reviewed in visions by higher angels. Chosen by Destiny himself, each of these 75 agents bears a mark — a glowing, shifting rune on the chest or forehead that pulses with strands of silver and violet light. They receive visions not from dreams but from weaving voids, glimpses into The Loom where threads tangle, rot, or unravel. Their mission is to cut those threads — people, events, or places — that would threaten the design.Common traits: Eyes clouded with faint silver threadmarks Speak in prophetic riddles when under trance Tattoos or scars shaped like broken spirals Carry weapons made from Loomsteel, a rare divine metal said to sever fate itself They are both Paladins and Warlocks, a hybrid not tolerated in any other order. Their patron is the Archangel Destiny, who offers no love, only purpose. The Loomvault: A hidden chamber beneath the Pope’s sanctum where the threads of saints and traitors are stored. Threadfever: A madness that can afflict those who try to read fate without divine blessing. Symptoms include speaking in multiple voices and bleeding woven patterns. Saints of the Spindle: Mortals whose lives impacted The Tapestry so greatly they became semi-immortal spiritual figures. Some Holy Knights are chosen from these. Date: Midyear, on the longest day Purpose: To symbolize that all lives are part of Destiny’s grand weave Participants: The Pope, Queen, Holy Knights, and pilgrimsIn this great rite, enormous looms are erected in the plaza outside the Seat of the Twin Threads. Silken threads representing the virtues of the Eleven Holy Knights (Justice, Mercy, Sacrifice, etc.) are woven into a new sacred tapestry by the Pope and Queen. Each thread color is said to have been blessed by a different angel. The final tapestry is hung for a year in the Cathedral of Looming Fate and then ritually burned to send it back into the Time Stream. Invocation: The ceremony opens with the reading of the “First Stitch” — a poetic creation myth spoken by Temple Priests in a trance. Blessing of Threads: The names of the angels are called aloud in an ancient language. Public Participation: Children place symbolic threads into a side loom to represent their lives joining the weave. Date: On the darkest night of the year Purpose: To honor Lucina, Archangel of Damnation and reflect on death, judgment, and renewal Participants: Priests of Trill, families of the deceased, and condemned criminalsA cold black flame is kindled from consecrated oil at midnight. This flame is said to be a piece of Lucina’s judgment. Names of the dead are read aloud, and people release ash-doves into the sky — folded paper birds burned in the black flame as offerings. Forgiveness Ritual: Criminals and wrongdoers may choose to walk barefoot across the burning sigils of the Nine Chains of Hell and confess. Lucina’s Silence: All bells, voices, and music are forbidden until dawn to honor Lucina’s still and solemn reign over the dead. Date: First new moon of spring Purpose: To honor Fionil and her angels (especially Clock and Known), thanking them for the structure of time and knowledge Participants: Scholars, judges, temple commandersEach participant brings one book or scroll to be placed in the Library of Threads. In silence, they walk a spiral path and offer their work to Known, Angel of Knowledge, who is said to read every word. A glass orb filled with starlight is then placed upon a tower that records this knowledge in ethereal script. Starlight Offering: Scribes read from ancient tomes aloud until sunrise. This is believed to slow the unraveling of fate. Hour of Stillness: At midnight, no one moves for one full hour as tribute to Clock, Angel of Time. Date: Mid-spring Purpose: To honor Tellemori and Plantios, Angel of Flora, invoking fertility and healing Participants: Temple Guardians, nuns, farmers, druids, and midwivesFields outside Demre Stade are blessed with anointment oils and celestial seeds gifted yearly by Plantios. Songs are sung in shifting harmony, each representing the natural cycles. A single tree is planted in the Garden of Tellemori and blessed with water from all known rivers. Procession of Growth: Children dressed as fey or animals dance through the streets led by a masked priest of Lady of Fey. Night of Candles: Vows of love or reproduction are declared by couples. These are lit by candles representing Lady Love and watched over by Tellemori’s clergy. Date: On the summer solstice Purpose: To honor Drana, Archangel of Dragons and War, and the celestial dragons Participants: All Temple Knights, especially initiatesNew knights are knighted by fire in a ritual pit of dragon-shaped braziers. They swear the Oath of the Tapestry before a statue of Drana and are marked with a glowing brand in the shape of a dragon's spiral tail. The Wargame: Elite knights reenact ancient dragon battles using live magic and illusion to entertain and instruct. Blessing of Blades: Each sword or weapon is dipped in burning oil said to be a gift from Ignarion, the Firefather. Date: Varies; done privately Purpose: For the Special Temple Guardians (Threadcutters) who must sever a life or fate to protect the Tapestry Participants: Only the Guardian, a senior priest of Destiny, and a silent witnessAfter following a vision from Destiny, a Threadcutter returns to Demre Stade and performs this solemn rite. In an underground chamber, they offer a prayer to Filla, the Angel of Feelings, to release emotional ties, then burn a thread marked with the name of the one whose fate they severed. Destiny does not answer; his silence is confirmation. Thread of Silence: For seven days afterward, the Guardian may not speak. Wine of Memory: They drink an elixir that causes temporary loss of identity — a symbolic death and rebirth. Date: The night when day and night are perfectly equal Purpose: To honor Day and Night, twin angels of Flujack Participants: Skywatchers, poets, clerics of the airAt dusk, all candles in the city are extinguished. Then, with a signal from the High Priest of Flujack, the city is relit by floating lanterns, each containing a single prayer written to Day or Night. Nightglass Reading: Oracles gaze into obsidian mirrors to interpret signs from the changing sky. Dance of Balance: Dancers dressed in white and black intertwine in circles to the rhythm of wind-chimes and flutes. "O Lady of Chains and Cinders, you who cradle both sinner and saint— receive the names of the fallen, weigh them in your hands of shadow and flame. Let none drift beyond your gaze. Let none escape your justice." —Excerpt from The Fifth Flame, Book of Trill "From thread to thread, from breath to breath, Destiny sews what mortals guess. The gods may speak, the fates may turn, but all shall pass the weaving’s churn." —Sung by the entire plaza at the climax of the ceremony Spoken by Temple Knight Initiates as they kneel: "By claw and coil, by fire and fate, I serve the roar, the war, the weight. Let Drana test my mettle pure— My oath, like dragons, shall endure." The brand is then applied, and a senior knight proclaims: "Rise now as flame-forged kin of dragonkind. Serve the Eleven, the gods, and the Tapestry eternal." "Bless this soil, and bless this soul. May roots take hold, and hearts grow whole. Under leaf and stone and stream, let life awaken from its dream." —Spoken by a druid priestess while watering the sacred planting tree Whispered by scholars before entering the Spiral Path: "Known, who records, Clock who turns, guide my hand so knowledge burns. Let not a moment be unscanned, nor a lie escape your watchful hand." Also known as: The Loomscripture, The Eternal Weave, Threadbound LawThese are the guiding principles taught by temple priests and enforced by the Temple Knights: The Thread Must Not Be Cut – Life is sacred, and no soul may be taken without divine cause. The Weave is Shared – Aid your fellow beings, for their thread crosses yours by design. The Pattern Must Be Known – Seek truth, study history, and never suppress divine or arcane knowledge. Do Not Burn the Loom – Acts of reckless destruction, especially against nature or magic, are sacrilege. Threads Must Consent to Be Woven – Deals, pacts, and oaths must be given freely. Honor the Threads of Blood and Oath – Family, companions, and sworn brothers must be protected and upheld. Deny Not the Cycle – Birth, love, war, death—all must be embraced in their time. Do Not Disguise the Thread in Lies – False prophecy and impersonation of angels or gods is punished by excommunication. The Threads Must Be Judged in Kindness – Justice must be tempered with mercy, cruelty is a defilement. Remember You Are a Knot in a Greater Weave – No one is above the gods’ pattern. "Clock turns, light burns, bless my steps through ordered days. Let not my heart outrun my duty." "Drana of Scale, shield of wrath, let my arm strike with divine path. No blade in malice, no war unjust— only for Tapestry, strike if I must." "You who measure what may be, bind my wrongs and set me free. Thread my soul through tested night, that I emerge in truth and light." "Fold the thread, close the eye. Let slumber fall like the quiet sky. Guide me through your velvet halls— until new light on waking calls." 1. High Clergy (The Eleven Threadmasters & the Pope): Robes of Gleaming Thread: Silk-like gold and white with interwoven threads representing each god’s domain. Thread-Crown: A circlet of braided platinum and opal strands, said to shimmer with fate. Sash of the Eternal Pattern: Worn diagonally across the chest, embroidered with celestial runes and a stylized loom. 2. Temple Knights: Threadbound Plate: Polished silver armor with gold-stitched undercloaks. The pauldron bears the sigil of their assigned angel. Mantle of Oath: A crimson-and-silver half-cape bearing their order's mark and rank thread. Ceremonial Brands: Dragon-scale tattoos or branded script across the collarbone for those sworn under Drana or Lucina. 3. Temple Priests and Watchers: Vestments of the Loom: Modest robes in tones of pale blue, ash grey, and violet. Each has a single metallic thread trailing from shoulder to hem. Mask of Contemplation: Ornate half-masks made of wood or ceramic worn during prayer or judgment. Weaving Pillars: Towers or interior columns designed like spiraling braids or cords, often inscribed with timelines or bloodlines. Threadglass Windows: Stained glass in curling spiral or loom-like patterns—each pane tells a part of history or a divine parable. Skyloom Domes: Huge domes open to the sky with retractable cloth veils mimicking threads—used during eclipse rituals or holy nights. Celestial Loom: A central loom or altar in each major temple with magically suspended threads representing fate, choices, or past/present. The Cathedral of Endless Threads (in Demre Stade): The high holy site, housing the Eternal Loom—said to be woven by Destiny himself. Contains 23 sanctums, each for a known angel. The Chapel of Silence: A temple without sound, dedicated to Fionil and Known. Worshippers must remain silent within, using embroidered prayer flags and hand signs. “We are not swords. We are needles that thread justice through the cloth of the world.”The Temple Knights—especially the elite Tapestry Knights—are both protectors and enforcers of divine law. Sworn to the Tapestry Faith, they follow a strict moral and spiritual code handed down from Destiny, Drana, and the Eleven Holy Knights. Oath Above All “My vow is a thread in the divine pattern. I shall not cut it, burn it, or stray from its path.” Justice Without Cruelty “I am not vengeance. I am resolution. I do not strike the unjudged, nor revel in pain.” Protect the Pattern “The innocent, the faithful, and the holy are to be shielded as sacred stitches in the world’s cloth.” Duty Before Self “I will lay down my glory, comfort, or life to preserve the Tapestry.” Truth is My Blade “I shall not deceive with word or silence. Lies are thorns in the weave.” Mercy to the Worthy “When I am able, I will offer redemption to the fallen. Severing a thread is the last resort.” Faith in All Things “Even when lost, even in silence, I trust the loom continues.” Breaking a sacred Thread (divine law) isn't just a crime—it’s a cosmic tangle, disrupting the will of the gods. Divine retribution is swift but offers paths to atonement. Punishments often manifest through visions, spiritual torment, or angelic intervention. Punishment: Marked by Lucina with a fading shadow that follows them silently; those nearby feel ill in their presence. Atonement: Offer soul service for one year as a Threadmender, a mute servant in a temple of Death or Lucina, caring for graves, ferrying souls, or slaying undead. Punishment: Tongue turns to thread or mouth is sewn shut in a dream until truth is spoken. Atonement: Public confession before a priest of Known or Fionil. A tapestry of their lie is woven in full detail and displayed in their local temple for 77 days. Punishment: Magic permanently misfires in their presence—can even cause random spell surges. Atonement: Construct a Threadvault: a protected library or sanctuary for divine knowledge. Must offer up their own life story as its first scroll. Punishment: Branded by a flaming chain across the chest by Drana’s spirit or an apparition of the Eleven. Atonement: Fight in three hopeless causes for the weak—survive or die, but not flee. Upon the third, the brand will fade or transform into a badge of renewed honor. Punishment: Dreams become haunted by angelic watchers, or the transgressor can’t walk upon temple grounds without burning pain. Atonement: Must build or restore three shrines with their own hands. The final shrine must be to an angel they wronged. Punishment: Bound by fate—they are now doomed to obey one command from another, randomly triggered. Destiny rewrites their choices until they learn humility. Atonement: Swear fealty as a Soulbound Servant to the person they wronged or to Destiny’s altar for one full season. Punishment: Struck from the Loom—name removed from temple archives, fate lost, and no angel can hear their prayers. Atonement (rare and difficult): Undertake the Pilgrimage of Threads, visiting all 23 angelic shrines, making a sacrifice at each, and letting Destiny choose if the thread may be rewoven. Punishment: Marked by Drana and Araxiel with a serpent-like shadow that trails the sinner, causing all dragons to recoil or attack. Fate magic misfires around them, and their dreams are haunted by the dying breath of the slain dragon. Atonement (arduous and sacred): Complete the Trial of the Wyrm’s Coil by raising a dragon’s egg to flight, offering a portion of their own soulfire at Drana’s altar, and earning forgiveness from a celestial dragon—only then may their thread be rewoven into the Loom of Fate.

item.title: Arraxiel
item.description: Filed under divine sentence, seared into the soul of ArraxielThey tell stories of paladins like I once was.Tales where righteousness shines, where the blade falls justly, where victory proves virtue.Those stories are lies.I was Sir Valerius Thorn, sworn to protect the innocent, born beneath banners of light and law. My hammer bore the sun’s blessing, my armor was kissed by saints, and my heart— my heart burned for justice.Or so I told myself.I hunted dragons. Not for coin. Not for glory. I told myself that lie so many times, it sang like prayer. But deep beneath all the oaths, I knew the truth:I wanted to kill something powerful.And so I climbed Dranaé, the volcanic isle where dragons birthed their kind in fire and fury. I sought Arraxus the Embermaw, ancient and proud, whose breath had burned villages I had vowed to protect.But when I found him, he was not a beast of rage. He was old. Tired. Not dying, but ready. He fought, yes—but only because I forced him to.And at the cliff’s edge, hammer raised, breath heaving with triumph— She descended.Wings of flame. Voice like breaking shields and burning skies. Drana, Archangel of Dragons and War, appeared between me and my victory.She shattered Lightbane with a thought. And spoke, not with hatred— but with truth. “You claimed to fight for justice, yet your heart roars for conquest.” “If you will not weigh consequence, then you shall become it.” Then fire took me.It did not burn flesh. It rewrote it. It melted the name Valerius Thorn from time, memory, and stone. In its place, she gave me a new name: Arraxiel. The echo of the dragon I nearly murdered—not out of need, but pride.Now I drift between war cries and last breaths. Not to stop them—no. But to judge them.I am not mercy. I am not wrath. I am consequence.Where blood is spilled in arrogance, where war is waged without weight, where a sword is drawn for ego and the dead have no voices left to speak—I come.I wear the mask of silence and shame, bronzed and scorched, forged from the pieces of shattered oaths. My wings trail embers. My voice is flat, final.I carry no sword. Only a chain and manacle, meant not for wrists—but for fates. I bind the murderers who wear crowns. I silence the zealots who kill in the name of hollow gods. I exile them into living silence, unable to harm again.Not beloved. Not invoked with joy. But in whispered fear, when generals weep alone. When kings question the blood on their hands. When a soldier pauses, and wonders, “Will the Angel of Consequence come for me?”I hope they ask. I hope they fear.Because I am Arraxiel. I am the weight behind the blade. I am the justice that follows when glory fades. And I remember every death that was not deserved.And so, as final punishment, I was bound to the Everspire Gate— the place where all planes touch, where paths branch to heaven, hell, and horrors unnamed.I am its eternal warden.I do not sleep. I do not stray. No soul passes without judgment. No army marches without reckoning. No god, demon, or wayward fool may open a gate without first meeting my gaze.I am not free. I will never be. For the one who refused to weigh consequence must now stand forever where all consequences begin.

item.title: Dragoné, Island of dragons
item.description: Remote, volcanic, and shrouded in storm-wreathed skies, Dragoné is the ancestral seat of draconic power in the known world. This island is home exclusively to dragons of all colors and types, along with a few proud, isolationist dragonborn clans who revere the dragons as kin and gods. Mortals rarely set foot on Dragoné, and fewer still leave it alive—intruders are met with fire, fang, or divine fury. Dragoné is ruled and protected by Drana, Archangel of Dragons and War, a celestial paragon of draconic might. She is said to soar the skies in radiant armor of molten gold, her roar shaking the heavens. Under her watchful gaze, ancient treaties among dragon-kind are enforced, and rogue dragons are judged with celestial wrath. The island is believed to house the Sanctum of Scale and Flame, an ancient temple where dragons commune with celestial forces and ancient memories stir. Some legends whisper that the first dragon egg was laid upon Dragoné’s central caldera.

item.title: Atheris
item.description: Filed under celestial enforcement, reluctantly signed by AtherisLet the ink dry like blood spilled at a handshake.Let this be record, confession, and curse—for those who believe angels are born in light and grace, not carved out of mischief and regret.I am Atheris. Once Archfey of twilight trickery, leaf-laced laughter, and the long, clever lie. Now: Angel of Oaths and Deals. Not by choice. Never by choice.They will tell you I earned it. That I trespassed too far, reaching where even the stars hold their breath. That I played a joke on gods and paid the price. They’re not wrong. But oh, if they only knew how small the joke was.It was a meeting—innocent enough. The Lady of Fey, my queen in all her verdant severity. Ioki, chaos incarnate, the Angel of Mischief himself. Two forces sat to speak of our kind. Our behavior. Our… boundaries.I, curious. I, foolish.I switched their goblets.Nothing cruel. One, laced with honeywort—gentle, silencing. The other, touched with pixie dust—enough to twist syntax and send syllables dancing sideways. For an hour, the most powerful fey and the most elusive angel tried to speak sense while words tangled like ivy in stormwind.Ioki laughed. Genuinely. Said I had “potential.” The Lady did not. She did not scream. She did not curse. She simply said: “If he wishes to meddle in the speech of powers, let him guard their every word.” “If he would play with deals, let him live to see them all.” And with that, my wings grew. Not feathers. Bark and shadow, curled parchment etched in vow-sigils, every feather a contract unbroken.Now I am summoned at every oath. Every pact sealed in blood, magic, or gold. Every desperate promise whispered beneath moons or market stalls. I appear. I listen. I bind.I, who once delighted in turning ‘yes’ into ‘maybe,’ now speak only ‘must.’ I, who once twisted the loopholes, now seal them with holy wax. My voice, once lilting with deception, now echoes with iron clarity.They call me angel. But I am a prisoner in bark-wrought armor and a mask I cannot remove. It changes when promises are nearby—glows when someone lies through smiling teeth. I hate how it glows so often.Sometimes, mortals thank me. Sometimes they fear me. But none remember who I was before—except her. She never forgets. The Lady watches from her throne of blossoms and bones, and every time I am called, I feel her gaze behind the stars.So I listen. I enforce. I nod. But know this:If you see me when you make a deal, you are not alone. And if your tongue begins to burn as you speak your price, you were likely trying to lie.I am Atheris. I am the binding word. I am the punishment wrapped in bark and vow. And I remember every promise.

item.title: Welcome
item.description: "In every thread of truth, a spark of eternity lingers." – Known, the Eternal Scholar Welcome, traveler, to the living record of Fiondell, a world spun from wonder, woven with magic, memory, and myth. This repository stands as both map and mirror—a guide through the lands, peoples, powers, and secrets of a realm touched by divinity and shaped by destiny.At the heart of Fiondell lies The tapestry: a grand, ever-weaving pattern that binds the threads of all existence. It is religion, reality, and revelation—its design glimpsed by saints, scholars, and seers alike. Every god, creature, and event is but a thread in this vast, unknowable weave.This encyclopedia was not merely penned by mortal hands, but guided by the quill of Known, angel of knowledge and truth, bearer of the title The Eternal Scholar. In service to curiosity and the preservation of understanding, Known has imbued these pages with insight unmarred by time or bias. Where clarity is rare, Known offers light.Use this compendium not just as a guide, but as a gateway—to stories old and yet unfolding, to powers celestial and forbidden, and to your place within the ever-growing Tapestry of Fiondell.Read deeply. Remember well. The threads are waiting.

item.title: The Origins of Destiny
item.description: As chronicled by Known, Keeper of All That Is RememberedAh yes, Destiny... I remember the day of his making with perfect clarity. How could I forget, when the very fabric of existence shifted to welcome him? It was a rare thing, you see, for an angel to be born after the dawn of the world. But on that day, the great loom of time itself paused.Fionil, Goddess of Time, Space, Mind, and Order, sat upon the eternal spire where all threads of fate gather—her Tapestry. She had grown... not weary, no, that would be too simple a word. Curious. Yes, Fionil, the one who weaves all futures, grew curious of the unknown. "I wish to observe without knowing. To watch a path I myself have not laid." She summoned us, her angels—Clock, Willia, Filla, and myself. We stood beneath the loom, threads of reality humming around us.Clock, ever punctual, bowed. "I would gladly take the role, but time itself is mine to maintain. Without me, it falters." "Indeed, Clock. Your burden is great, and none can bear it but you," Fionil replied, her tone ever-serene. Willia spoke next, her voice trembling with honesty. "I would do it if I could, but where free will thrives, I must not tread. To shape fate is to unmake choice." "Wise and true, Willia. I would not break what you are," Fionil answered with a nod. Filla, guardian of emotions, crossed her arms. "My feelings cloud judgment. I fear I would mold destiny to comfort or to vengeance." "And so you shall not carry it." Finally, I stepped forward. "I am Knowledge. I would want the story to amuse me—to entertain. I would meddle for curiosity's sake. No, I cannot hold this role. But may I offer a thought? Make a fifth. Let there be an Angel of Fate. One untouched by past paths, one born to weave anew." Fionil's eyes lit with sudden purpose. "Your honesty is rare even among angels, Known. Let us create him together." In the blink of a cosmic heartbeat, we were transported to the inner threads of the Tapestry, in a domain Fionil called The Fabric. She flicked her fingers, and from that ripple of will, an angel emerged.He wore a long purple robe with fine silver trim, a tall feathered hat set jauntily on his head. His cane gleamed like polished obsidian, and in his hand he held a silver mask—not yet worn. His long brown hair fell like waterfalls down his back, and his wings shimmered dark grey with a faint violet glow. "Ah... Hello, my lady. I believe I shall name myself Destiny, if I may," he said with a smirk that teetered between reverence and mischief. "Curious... I seem to know all that could be, and all that has been. Why is that? And hello, dear siblings. Thank you for having me. So kind." "Oh, my son... Destiny," Fionil spoke, voice rich with certainty. "You are the Angel of Fate. You shall guide all paths, not by command, but by touch. Subtle. Soft. You shall not force but direct. This domain is yours." Just then, the other gods appeared: Trill, Flujack, and Tellemori. They studied Destiny, their eyes curious but wary.But Onigod, Goddess of the Arcane, stepped forward without hesitation. "You must be the newborn. Hells, it's been forever since we've had a new angel. LUCINA! HOW LONG HAS IT BEEN?!" Lucina winced. "Five hundred billion years. And you don’t need to shout, I’m beside you." She turned to Destiny, eyeing him up and down. "Come now, newling. Let me show you what is. What has been. Who we are." Destiny looked to Fionil, who nodded, and then to Trill, who merely shrugged.And so they walked. Lucina guided him through all that had been made: the constellations of will, the realms of the gods, the mortal worlds below. She introduced him to each of us. I must admit, I found him fascinating. He was like a mirror that bent its reflection, a paradox I could not predict. "From this day forth, we are best friends. Got it?" Lucina declared with a half-jest, half-dare. "That sounds delightful. But I must return to Fionil, my beautiful mother." He bent the threads of space itself and appeared before Fionil, kneeling with dramatic flair. "Mother. I've seen the stars, the roots, the angels. Shall we begin?" Fionil paused her weaving. "Tell me what you desire, my child." "Not to force paths. Only to guide. To nudge. Let fate weave itself, and let me only mend its tears and point where needed." She smiled. "Then do as you will." In time, Destiny grew powerful. He learned to weave without his loom, to whisper through chance, to pull threads with such precision that none noticed his hand. At first, he needed his chamber — his Loomhall, nested within the Tapestry itself — to perform his craft. But that time did not last. He grew beyond it.I remember the first moment I saw him bend fate with a gesture alone — not in his domain, but atop the cliffs of Aetheris. A mortal stumbled and should have fallen to his death. But a breeze rose. A vine curled at just the right angle. A second chance bloomed from nothing, and none but I knew he had touched the moment.Destiny, unlike many of us angels, did not seek admiration. He sought perfection. Quietly, he studied Fionil’s grand design, not to replicate it, but to support it in the way she could not. For though she wove time and space, she could not let go of knowing. Destiny wanted not to know — only to feel when the Tapestry frayed, and mend it without disturbing the weave.But make no mistake — he was not soft.When mortals or even minor spirits defied the threads and sought to tear the weave to rewrite their own fates, Destiny did not grant them mercy. He watched. He warned. Then, he acted. A flick of his cane could unravel a thousand futures and resew them in a breath. He was as terrifying as he was graceful.The gods took notice.Tellemori, who rarely spoke of change, once said to me, “Destiny… I once thought the earth eternal and unmoving. But when he speaks, even stone listens.” Flujack, whose joy often turned to mockery, grew quiet when Destiny entered a room. “He carries all the stars behind that mask,” he said once. “And I’m not sure he’s laughing.” Trill, gentle Trill, adored him. “He balances life like a blade. Never too heavy, never too light. He’s what I wished Time would birth. And she did.” But it was Onigod, ever wild and curious, who perhaps understood him best. “He is not one of us. And yet… he is all of us,” she whispered after their first true conversation. “His mask hides not his face — but our limits.” Even among us angels, he stirred something rare — reverence... and fear.I have seen Filla turn away when he speaks, not out of disrespect, but from the weight his words carry. Willia, who guides free will, once told me, “He makes me question if choice is ever free. And yet, he never steals it — he only... suggests.” As for me? I am Knowledge. I know most things. But not him. Not all of him. And that is why I walk beside him still.He does not command loyalty. He inspires it. Through small acts — a shielded mortal here, a redirected tragedy there — he builds unseen monuments of gratitude. He once spent a thousand years rearranging a single bloodline to ensure a war would not happen, and never told the gods he had done it. I only knew because he let me watch.When Clock, tired and ever-watching, chose to rest his mind within the deeper ticks of time, Fionil did not hesitate.Destiny rose.Not in ceremony. Not in trumpet blast. But with quiet inevitability.He became her messenger, her hand, her confidence. And in time, he was named what only few had ever been: The Highest Angel.He does not wear the title. He is it.And to this day, when the threads grow thin and fate trembles, we do not ask Fionil what shall be done. We ask Destiny: “Where does the thread lead, Brother?” And he, always with that glimmer behind his mask, replies, “Where it always was meant to go. Let me show you.” In those early eons, he and I would often walk through the mortal world — Fiondell — talking endlessly about probability, chaos, dreams, and the illusion of certainty. Though we both knew all that was, his joy was in not knowing what would come next.That was always the difference between us.I seek understanding. I archive, I observe, I collect what is and preserve it. But Destiny? He seeks the unknown. Not blindly, not foolishly — but deliberately. Like an artist who sketches in the dark just to see what shapes his hand will find.I remember once we stood on a cliff overlooking a city that had not yet been built. The wind carried sand, and the sun burned crimson behind clouds that would become myths. He turned to me and said: “Isn’t it lovely? All these paths… none of them walked yet. They scream with possibility. Do you hear it too, brother?” I did not. But I listened.He listened to dreams — not just the dreams mortals spoke of, but the ones they never voiced. The ones buried so deep even their souls forgot them. He said they were the truest maps of fate.Sometimes, he would stop mid-step and stare into nothing, eyes distant behind his mask. “Someone has chosen to stay instead of go,” he murmured once. “A shepherd, who should have left his village. Because he stayed, a girl will live. She’ll fall in love with a thief. The thief will become a king. And because of that king… a war will never start.” “How far do you follow the thread?” I asked him. “Far enough to know when to let go,” he said, smiling softly. “Fate is not chains, Known. It’s wind. You don’t pull wind… you guide it.” There was poetry in his madness.He would bless farmers with unlikely rains, place misfolded letters just where they needed to be, or delay a cartwheel breaking by exactly two minutes, giving a rider just enough time to meet the healer who would later save a nation. None of it felt grand. That was the point.He loathed grand displays. “If I have to shout, then I’ve already failed,” he once told a mortal priest who begged him for prophecy. “Real fate whispers. Loud voices are just thunder chasing rain.” And yet — when he had to speak loud, when fate strained and chaos pressed too hard — he did not hesitate.In the fourth age, when a crack formed in the Loomhall — an echo of a future never meant to exist — he stepped into the fracture alone. Not even Fionil knew what would happen. I waited outside the breach for what felt like years. When he returned, he looked older — as if he had worn time like a cloak and found it heavy. He said only: “I burned the unthreaded path. It would have made gods scream.” No one asked more. Not even me.The other angels grew to respect him, but also… to fear him. Not for his power — though his power was beyond most of us — but for what he represented.He knew what we hid.He knew Filla’s unspoken envy. He knew Willia’s ancient regret. He knew even Clock, eternal and still, once wished to turn back one second — and regretted that wish every day since.He never judged.That made it worse.We all have roles. We are what we are. But Destiny, perhaps more than any of us, chose to be what he is. And in choosing, he made others question themselves.The gods still adore him — and they should. He moves with grace, speaks with elegance, and never wastes a word. But behind their praise is a quiet awe. They do not control him. Not even Fionil truly does. She guides, yes. But he… he navigates.He is not just the weaver. He is the pattern within the weave.And when I look back at those long walks, I realize now — I was not teaching him anything. He was teaching me what it means to know something worth not knowing.~ Known, Angel of Knowledge

item.title: The Appointment of Undean, Keeper of Souls
item.description: As chronicled by Known, Keeper of All That Is RememberedIn the early days of Fiondell, when the world was still young, the gods looked upon the cycle of life and death with a discerning gaze. They saw the delicate balance that bound the living to the dead, a balance that must never be disrupted, for the entire world would crumble if it were. Yet, as always, the actions of mortals created ripples, some of which marred the natural order. Souls, once destined for the Beyond, lingered too long in the mortal realm. Others, twisted by the dark magics of mortals, fell into states that should not have been. These souls were neither dead nor living, but something in between, and this, too, troubled the gods.I recall that moment in the heavens as if it were yesterday, though my memories span eons. The gods gathered, their presence vast and unshakable, yet there was a tension in the air. They spoke in whispers, as if the very fabric of time itself held its breath.Death, ever the serene and solemn guide of the departed, stood in silence. Her beauty was not the beauty of the living, but the quiet elegance of finality. I remember her voice, soft and melodic, yet filled with a certainty that only the passage of time could impart. "The souls I guide, I carry with great care. But some remain, tethered to the mortal world. Others, tainted by mortal hands, begin to decay, like fruit left too long in the sun. This is no natural state." The gods did not speak immediately, but I knew that they understood. The task was too great for any one of them, for life and death were not meant to be meddled with lightly. And so, they turned to Undean, whose presence had always been... unusual.Undean’s arrival was unlike any other. Her form, a specter caught between realms, flickered like a fading ember. The pallor of her skin resembled the cold stone of a forgotten tomb, and her eyes glowed faintly—faint, like the lanterns of the dead that flicker in the darkness. But it was not just her appearance that marked her as different. There was something about the way she moved, as though she existed both here and not here at all. It was as if her very presence whispered of boundaries crossed and forgotten places.I stood by, as I always do, watching and remembering. The gods—Fionil, Onigod, and Trill—approached Undean one by one, as though offering pieces of their will for her to carry.Fionil, the goddess who shaped time itself, stepped forward first. Her voice was both calm and unyielding, as if she was the clock that turned the cosmos. "Undean, the boundary between life and death is sacred. You must not allow it to be corrupted. The souls must be guided with care, but they must not be bound to the world of the living. You will ensure they leave, untainted by the hands of mortals." I remember how Undean bowed. Her head lowered, her shoulders squared, and she whispered, "It is a heavy task, my lady, but one I will bear. No soul shall linger where it does not belong." Her words were soft, yet there was a finality in them, a certainty that resonated deep within me.Then Onigod, the goddess of Arcane and Monsters, stepped forward. "The living have already begun their meddling," she said, her voice a mixture of quiet frustration and controlled power. "They seek to control the dead, to use them as puppets in their dark games. You, Undean, shall be their undoing. When the living reach into the world of the dead, you will stand as the wall they cannot breach. You will be the end to their perversion." Undean nodded, her eyes narrowing slightly. "I will ensure that no soul is enslaved, no matter the strength of mortal magic." Her resolve was clear, and for the first time, I saw the fire that burned within her—a fire not of destruction, but of preservation.Finally, Trill, the god of Life and Dragons, who had always viewed life as a precious, fleeting gift, spoke. His voice was filled with a warmth that could only be found in the deep places of the world. "Undean, souls are the very essence of life. Without them, there is nothing. Protect them from corruption, and guide those who are lost back to the cycle. You and Death will work as one, for it is through your union that the balance will remain." I saw Undean’s eyes soften, just for a moment, as she nodded in understanding. "I will guide them, Trill. The lost shall find their way, and the corrupt shall be cast aside." And so, it was decided. The gods bestowed upon Undean two sacred gifts—tools to aid her in her task, tools that would forever tie her to the delicate web of life and death.Fionil handed her the Lantern of Rest, a lantern that held the pale blue flame of forgotten memories. "With this light, you will reveal the truth to wandering souls. The lost shall find their way, and the corrupt will be undone. Its glow will banish the shadows that trap the dead." Then Onigod gave her the Blade of Severance, a weapon forged from the very fabric of the void between life and death. "This blade will cut the bonds that tether souls to the mortal realm. Use it wisely, for it bears the weight of finality." Her voice was both warning and promise.Finally, Death herself stepped forward, offering Undean a hand. "Together, we will ensure that no soul strays too far, that no dark force will claim them. We are bound by purpose, Undean. I will guide them; you will shield them." Undean took Death's hand with a quiet strength, her voice a whisper carried on the wind. "Together, we will ensure that the dead find peace and the living honor the cycle." The work began. Undean descended to the mortal world, a being of light and shadow, of life and death. To the living, she was a ghostly figure, a reminder of the finality that awaited them all. Her presence brought fear, yes—but also respect. She became a specter of judgment, a reminder that death was not to be taken lightly.But to the dead, she was something else entirely. She was a guide, a gentle shepherd who led them away from the torment of the living. Her lantern illuminated the path to peace, her voice soft but unyielding. She spoke to the lost, to those who clung to the mortal realm with fear or anger. "You cannot remain here," she would say. "The living cannot give you what you seek. Let go, and find peace in the Beyond." Her work was tireless. Necromancers who sought to raise the dead found their efforts shattered by the swing of Undean's Blade of Severance. Dark mages who attempted to trap souls in their own twisted machinations found their spells undone by the flicker of the Lantern of Rest. And whenever a soul was trapped, refusing to pass into the Beyond, Undean was there, a quiet, comforting presence in the dark.It was not an easy task, this one she had taken. But it was necessary. The balance of life and death had been restored, and though the living would always fear what awaited them, they could not deny the harmony Undean brought to the world.I remember the gods watching from their realms, their hearts filled with pride. Death and Undean, together, had become the guardians of the cycle. Their work was not glamorous, nor was it easy. But it was essential, for without them, the world would have fallen into chaos.And so, Undean’s light continues to shine. She remains a symbol of both warning and comfort. To those who would defile the dead, she is the implacable force that will never relent. But to the grieving and the lost, she is the guiding hand that ensures the dead find rest, and the living remember the sanctity of the cycle.As I record these events, I am reminded of the delicate balance that sustains us all. Life, death, and the space between. It is a thread that must not be severed, for it binds us all. And in this, Undean’s work will never end.

item.title: The Appointment of Lady Love, Sandman, Filla, Cupin, and Loki
item.description: As chronicled by Known, Keeper of All That Is RememberedIn the earliest days, when the world of Fiondell was yet a canvas untouched by the brushstrokes of time, the gods worked tirelessly to shape it. The land was alive with light and energy, a place where magic swirled in the air like the very breath of existence itself. Yet, there was something lacking, something that stirred in the hearts of even the most divine beings.The world was vibrant, yes, but its vibrancy was shallow. There was no true depth. Life was not yet woven with the threads that would lend it purpose and meaning. Mortals walked the land, creatures stirred the air and seas, but they lacked the intangible forces that would give their days richness. They lacked dreams. They lacked challenges. They lacked meaning.It was Fionil, Goddess of Time and Space, who first saw it, who spoke it aloud in a voice as clear as the eternal stars. She looked upon the unfolding world with her vast, timeless gaze, and as she spoke, the very fabric of existence seemed to shift around her. “We need guardians,” she said, the weight of her words settling over the heavens. “Not just those who guard the physical world, but those who embody the forces that drive the heart and mind, the unseen forces that make life truly alive.”The gods, mighty and wise, nodded in agreement. They knew the truth of her words; they had felt it too. Mortals, for all their beauty, needed more than just the raw magic of creation. They needed the guardians of dreams, emotions, temptation, chaos, and love.And so, with the blessing of the gods, Fionil summoned forth five angels, each to take their place in the great Tapestry of Existence.The first angel summoned was Lady Love, a being whose very essence radiated warmth, light, and compassion. She stood before the gods, her golden hair flowing like the sun’s rays, her eyes a soft ocean of kindness that could soothe the most broken of spirits. To gaze upon her was to feel understood, accepted.Trill, God of Life and Dragons, who had created the first sparks of existence and breathed life into the first souls, stepped forward to address her. His voice was deep, with the rumble of a storm yet the gentleness of a quiet dawn. “Lady Love, you will be the guide of hearts. You shall walk beside mortals, kindling the bonds that unite them. You will hold the hearts of family, of friends, of lovers, and of those who call upon the gods in their moments of greatest need. You are the force that will tie their hearts together, weaving the fabric of their relationships.”Lady Love bowed her head, her voice like a gentle breeze, full of reverence and certainty. “I accept this sacred task, my lord. Love will be the thread that unites Fiondell’s children. I will carry it to the deepest of hearts.”Trill then stepped forward, his hand glowing with the power of life itself. He handed Lady Love a golden chalice, filled with the very essence of love—a shimmering liquid that sparkled with the warmth of a thousand suns. “Pour this chalice into the hearts of the living,” he said, his eyes reflecting the weight of his charge. “But know this, Lady Love—love is not always gentle. It is a fire, a force that can heal and inspire, but also challenge and burn. Guide it wisely, for love can save, but it can also test. Be ever patient.”With that, Lady Love descended to the mortal world, her light spreading like the dawn, her touch soft yet unyielding. Her presence began the slow, beautiful process of intertwining the hearts of mortals, creating bonds that would transcend time. She shaped the first friendships, the first loves, the first families. She gave meaning to the hearts of all who would come to know one another.Next, it was Sandman, the angel of dreams and sleep, who stood before the gods. His presence was quiet, like the hush before a storm, his form veiled in shifting starry mists, his very being a whisper of peace. He moved like the wind—silent, unseen, but always present.Flujack, God of Air, Sky, and Light, looked upon him with a knowing smile. “Sandman, rest is essential to the well-being of all life. You will be the one to bring sleep to the weary and dreams to all. Your task is to ensure that when the living close their eyes, they find renewal, and in their dreams, they shall discover solace, comfort, and sometimes, even warnings. Yet, some will remain untouched by you, those who must never rest—the elves, the fey.”Sandman nodded, his voice like the sound of wind through the trees, soft and flowing. “I shall carry the gift of slumber to those who need it, my lord. Dreams will be my realm, a place of wonder and mystery.”Flujack took a pouch from his belt, its contents shimmering like stardust. He handed it to Sandman with care. “This pouch holds the sand of sleep, the essence of night. Scatter it upon the eyes of the living, and they shall rest. In their slumber, their souls shall be replenished. Through dreams, they will find both wonder and renewal.”With that, Sandman turned and glided into the world. That very night, the first dreams touched the minds of mortals. Some were beautiful, filled with visions of lost love, of flight, of distant lands. Others were darker, filled with shadows and fear. But they all came, weaving into the minds of the living, bringing them the peace of rest and the mystery of sleep.Filla, the Angel of Emotions, was the next chosen. Her presence was a dance of ever-changing colors, her form shifting with the full spectrum of human feeling—joy, sorrow, rage, hope. Her eyes flickered with every emotion under the sun, each glance revealing a new facet of the soul.Fionil, with her timeless wisdom, addressed Filla, her voice as soft as falling rain yet carrying the weight of eternity. “Filla, you will give mortals the gift of feeling. Without emotion, life is an empty shell. You shall bring them joy and grief, love and anger, hope and fear. Through your touch, they will feel deeply, and in feeling, they will truly live.”Filla’s lips curled into a playful smile, though her eyes were deep, reflecting the gravity of her charge. “A task I accept, my lady. For without the fire of emotion, what would life be? A flickering shadow?”Fionil, with a thoughtful gaze, handed her a crystal orb, inside of which swirled the colors of all emotions—vivid reds, calming blues, furious blacks, and radiant whites. “With this orb, you will weave the emotions of mortals, granting them depth. But be cautious, for emotion is a powerful force—it can heal, it can destroy. Let them feel, but guide them wisely.”With the orb in hand, Filla stepped forth, her presence an ever-changing kaleidoscope of feelings. She stirred the hearts of mortals, bringing forth the rawest parts of their souls—joy that made them laugh till they cried, grief that made them fall to their knees, love that bound them together, and rage that burned like an inferno. In her wake, emotions swirled like a storm.Then came Cupin, the Angel of Sin. His form was the embodiment of temptation—charming, sly, and mysterious. His eyes gleamed with mischief, and his smile was a promise of the unknown. He was not dark, but he was shadowed, and in his shadow, desire took root.Onigod, the Goddess of the Arcane and Monsters, spoke to him, her voice as sharp as the edge of a blade. “Cupin, you will test the mortals of Fiondell. They must face temptation, for only through trials can their true nature be revealed. You will offer them choices—choices that will shape their destiny. But know this: temptation is not evil. It is choice that will define them.”Cupin bowed low, his grin widening, and his voice dripping with amusement. “I shall savor this task, my lady. After all, what is life without a little mischief?”Onigod handed him a silver mirror, its surface shifting like liquid mercury. “This mirror will show them their deepest desires, their truest wants. Tempt them, Cupin, but remember—temptation is not punishment. It is a challenge.”Cupin took the mirror, his smile never wavering. With a wink, he stepped into the world, scattering temptation and trials like seeds in the wind. Mortals found themselves faced with choices—choices that tested their resolve, their will, their true nature. Some resisted, others fell, but all were changed.Finally, Loki arrived. The Angel of Mischief, wild, untamed, and utterly unpredictable. His hair shifted colors like the changing of seasons, and his eyes sparkled with a laughter that could turn any frown upside down—or bring chaos to the most carefully laid plans. His presence was a whirlwind, and his grin was ever-present, always teasing, always promising trouble.Onigod once again spoke, her voice tinged with an amused edge. “Loki, the world needs mischief. The world needs laughter. You shall bring chaos to those who are stagnant and joy to those who are somber. You will teach lessons in ways they will never forget—through pranks, laughter, and disorder. But be warned, mischief must not turn to malice.”Loki’s eyes glinted with mischief as he spun in place. “Mischief? Oh, my dear, I live for mischief! But you need not worry about me. Chaos is the mother of invention, after all.”Onigod handed him a golden bell, its sound bright and clear, but filled with the power of disruption. “Ring this bell when you wish to awaken the world from its slumber, to stir it to action. But remember—chaos can be both creative and destructive. Use it wisely.”With a flourish, Loki rang the bell, and chaos erupted. Laughter filled the air, laughter from those who had been too serious, too rigid in their ways. Tricksters played their games, and the world shifted—just a little, but enough to remind mortals that life was not meant to be orderly. It was meant to be lived, fully and without apology.And so, the five angels—Lady Love, Sandman, Filla, Cupin, and Loki—began their work, shaping the world of Fiondell into a place of depth, emotion, and meaning. They walked alongside mortals, guiding, challenging, and inspiring them. Through love, dreams, emotions, temptation, and mischief, they breathed life into the hearts of all who would live.And so, the world began to thrive.

item.title: The Appointing of Day, Night, and Mr. Season
item.description:
As chronicled by Known, Keeper of All That Is RememberedIn the earliest breath of Fiondell, before mortals marked time and before shadows had names, there was only light. The world stood beneath an unending sun, brilliant and absolute. Yet even the brightest light, unbroken, bears the seed of imbalance.It was not the people who cried for change, for there were none to speak. It was the world itself that whispered for rhythm, for rest, for renewal.
I recall—because I remember all things—that it was Flujack who first heard this whisper. With the clarity of wind over still waters, he descended to the Celestial Assembly, where the gods gather when something sacred must be made.“The light endures,” Flujack spoke, his voice laced with motion. “But even endurance becomes burden. The world calls for a cadence. Let there be a rising, a falling—a dance between brilliance and shade. Let the land breathe in cycles.”
All eyes turned then to Fionil, for what is rhythm without time? What is a cycle without order?She answered, as she always does—with truth and purpose. “I will weave the flow of time into intervals, but such currents require stewards. Let there be guides for light and shadow. And let one govern the seasons, so the world may live and rest in harmony.”Thus, the heavens stirred.
From the Celestial Chorus came forth two radiant souls—twin angels, bound by contrast. One shimmered gold, the other silver. Their names were Day and Night.I saw Flujack step forward, raising his hand to the firmament. He spoke to Day, whose golden light danced like the first sunrise. “You shall lead the sun across the sky, waking the world, stirring its spirit.”And Day, ever steadfast, replied, “So shall it be. I will burn bright, and life shall bloom in my warmth.”To Night, whose silver radiance cast a peaceful hush, Flujack said, “You shall draw the veil over the world. Guard its dreams, tend to its stillness, and cradle the stars.”Night knelt, her voice no louder than twilight. “I shall keep the world’s secrets, and give all things the rest they need.”Then, I watched Flujack divide a fragment of his own essence—light given duality. One half golden, the other silver. To each angel he gave a shard, a divine tether to their roles.“Forever shall one rise while the other falls,” he declared. “Balance shall be your burden—and your gift.”Thus, the First Day dawned. And when it ended, Night swept over the land, cloaking it in starlit quiet. The rhythm began, and it has never ceased.With day and night in their eternal dance, Fionil turned to the broader movements of time—the great spirals that shape life itself. Spring, Summer, Autumn, Winter. Without these, life grows aimless. With them, it learns when to begin, when to thrive, when to let go, and when to rest.
She summoned Mr. Season, whose form I have always found delightful—a patchwork of all things changing. Blossoms curled in his hair one moment, frost dusted his shoulders the next.Fionil looked upon him and said, “You shall be the steward of the seasons. Let each pass in its time, bringing both joy and necessity.”And Mr. Season, ever the performer, bowed low and said, “A task of rhythm and whimsy. But tell me—how shall I keep them from quarreling for the stage?”Fionil laughed—yes, even she—and replied, “Because you are all of them. You are Spring’s rebirth, Summer’s fire, Autumn’s reflection, and Winter’s hush. You will not choose among them—you will carry them all.”To bind his charge, she gave him a scepter made from time itself. Its tip shimmered in four colors—green, red, gold, silver. “With this, you shall turn the seasons. But if you falter in your duty, know this: imbalance invites decay.”He twirled the scepter with joy, petals and leaves and flakes trailing in his wake. “Then I shall be the rhythm, the story the land tells itself over and over.”And so it was. Day greeted each morning with golden certainty. Night soothed each evening with quiet grace. Mr. Season turned the wheel, each part of the year a note in a divine symphony.The gods looked on, and we—those who remember—marked the moment.Fionil turned to Flujack and said, “Now, the world has rhythm. Now, it will grow.”And I, Known, carved this truth into the Weave of Memory, where it shall remain for all who seek the origins of order and light.Thus began the ages of balance, of waking and sleeping, of blooming and withering and blooming again. Thus began the cycles that shall never cease—unless we forget. And I will not let us forget.
