item.title: The Truth Behind the First Dragonborn
item.description: As chronicled by Known, Keeper of All That Is RememberedMany speak of the Dragonborn as a race forged from fire and fate, their origin painted in either glory or transgression. But I, Known—who watches not through time, but through truth—have held the memory of their beginning within the depths of my eternal archives. Let me unseal it now for those who seek more than legend.The tale begins when Fiondell was still young, its mountains unwrinkled and its seas unsullied by blood. The gods had not yet retreated fully from the world, and their angels walked freely among mortals, shaping, watching… interfering.Two among them—Cupin, Angel of Sin, and Loki, Angel of Mischief—grew restless in the quiet between ages. “Let’s create something unique,” Cupin whispered, eyes alight with wicked brilliance, as if daring the world itself to object. “Something… unexpected. A creature that defies both the order of Fionil and the careful design of Trill.” “Yes,” Loki grinned, thunder coiling faintly in his voice. “Something neither beast nor man. A blend. A gamble.” I remember the silence that followed. Even the stars hesitated to blink.Their plan was not born of malice, nor benevolence. It was born of curiosity, that twin-edged impulse that so often births both wonders and catastrophes.Loki stole a human soul—an act of deep transgression. He bound it within a soul cage, a vessel that should not exist, twisting the strands of destiny like a spider tugging at another’s web. This drew the attention of Livius, Angel of Life, whose sense of balance runs deeper than the roots of the world. “What are you doing, Loki?” Livius asked, descending in a column of radiant wind. His voice was steady, but firm—a man trying to stop a storm with logic. Loki only shrugged, flicking the soul cage like a toy. “An experiment, dear Livius. Wouldn’t you like to see the result?” “I would prefer to see balance maintained,” Livius replied. But he did not intervene. He never does, not at first. He lets the pieces fall, and only when they settle does he move them.The soul was cast across the realms, where Cupin caught it like a flame in the palm of her hand. To it, she added a second soul—that of a stillborn dragon, one never destined to know life. She did not mourn it. She used it.Their essences coiled and writhed, resisting, clashing, then… merging.I have seen many souls born, shaped, fractured, consumed. But this union—this blend of draconic fire and mortal will—it sang with a strange harmony. Cupin, fascinated, began to weave a body for it. Not perfect, not beautiful—but powerful. “Loki, Drana, Livius!” Cupin called when she was done. “Behold my creation!” They arrived.Drana, the Archangel of Dragons, was the first to speak, her wings drawn close in quiet outrage. “Why do you tamper with dragonkind?” she hissed. “This being bears the blood of my kin. Is there no retribution for this theft?” “Drana,” Livius murmured, “they act within the bounds of their natures. Cupin tempts. Loki misleads. And you—” his voice was gentle but unyielding, “—must now decide whether to protect or destroy.” “It is not my decision,” she growled. “It is Trill’s.” Indeed. The soul-child was lifted by divine hands and brought to the Plane of the Gods, to the Silver Halls where Trill, god of Life and Dragons, and Fionil, goddess of Time and Order, debated the fates of entire peoples over silent cups of stardust.But the gods were not the first to greet the arriving angels.Destiny awaited them at the threshold. Of course he did. “Well, well!” he chuckled, idly flipping an hourglass filled with singing sand. “My favorite meddlers bring me such curiosities. What do we have here, I wonder? No, don’t tell me—let me guess. Ah, yes. Trill.” His eyes glinted with something I never quite deciphered. “But I wonder what Fionil will say…” They were admitted.Fionil sat in stillness, her hands never moving, her gaze locked upon the infinite tapestry of time where all things—past, future, even possibility—unfolded in real time. Trill stood beside her, ever the builder, ever the dreamer of new life. “Fionil, Trill,” Destiny announced with a grand sweep of his arm, “may I present a creation. A fusion of human soul and dragon essence. A dragonborn, if you will.” The name—dragonborn—did not exist until that moment. But it stuck.Trill stepped forward first, and I saw the flicker in his eyes: not outrage, not horror… but hope. “Loki, Cupin,” he said, with a voice like rolling thunder made kind, “you have done well. This being is a bridge. Not an abomination. It shall dwell in Fiondell, and I shall prepare a place for it.” Fionil, never swayed by passion, offered only this: “Let them walk among the mortals. Let them choose. Let them shape their own future. That is the only way destiny becomes real.” And thus, the Dragonborn were given the world.Not as punishment. Not as weapons. But as a gift—born of chaos, but blessed with potential.And Trill spoke, and I remember: “In this being, I see the potential of unity. A soul uniting the wisdom of dragons and the spirit of mortals. They shall bridge our creations, standing as guardians of balance.” And Fionil, weaving time around them like thread, said: “The Dragonborn shall walk among mortals, free to choose their path. Whether they lead in wisdom or fall to their own desires, their choices shall shape the destiny of Fiondell.” I, Known, have recorded this tale not merely for truth, but for understanding. The Dragonborn are not creatures of sin or mischief. They are reminders.That sometimes, the unexpected carries the greatest promise.That even the gods do not always know what they are doing.That chaos, when tempered by purpose, can give birth to greatness.Let this memory remain.Let it be.—Known

item.title: The Origin of the Tieflings
item.description: As chronicled by Known, Keeper of All That Is RememberedIn the age before permanence—when the winds carved mountains and time flowed without shape—the Five labored. Each god, in their manner, shaped the world of Fiondell from the unspoken and the unseen. Among them, Fionil, She Who Orders the Eternal Clock, and Trill, the Giver of Breath and Flame, envisioned a race unlike those that had come before.They did not seek perfection, nor simplicity. They sought paradox.It was then that they turned to Destiny, the Angel who walks between beginnings and endings. I recall the way Destiny moved: not across space, but through meaning. When given this task, he did not hesitate. He descended—not with fear, but with purpose—into the dominion ruled by Lucina, the Angel of Damnation, the Flame Unyielding, the Architect of Hell.Understand this: Lucina is often misunderstood. Her domain is not cruelty, but consequence. Her fire does not punish—it reveals. When Destiny came to her, it was not with chains or orders, but an invitation to co-create. That, too, is worth remembering.Destiny spoke thus: “I am sent not to dictate, but to learn. The gods above seek a new people—one born of light and shadow, of purpose and uncertainty. What spark may you lend to such a creation?” Lucina, in her brilliance, smiled—not cruelly, but knowingly. Her reply was a vision in motion. “Let them be marked, not marred. Let them wear the sigils of fire and strength—horns as crowns, tails as balance, eyes as windows to soulfire. Let them walk through flames and speak with voices shaped by embers. Let them reflect the truth that even the infernal can inspire beauty.” And so it was shared. Destiny returned to the heavens, bearing no weapon, only a memory. In the presence of Fionil and Trill, he unraveled Lucina’s vision not as a servant, but as a witness.Fionil, ever measured, did not recoil. She observed. She saw in the vision a kind of order: not of symmetry, but of interwoven contradiction. She wove the first threads.Trill, whose breath brings motion to stillness, smiled at the sight. He recognized life in it—not only breath and blood, but spirit. With reverence, he gave form to what had been dreamt.Thus were born the Tieflings.They were not cursed, as some would later whisper. Nor were they wholly blessed. They were—like all who walk between extremes—a question made flesh. Fire kindled in mortal veins. Strength shaped by shame, pride, and perseverance. A people with no single origin, yet tied by one thread: they were meant.To some, they are reminders of hell. To others, of resilience. But I, Known, record not judgment—only truth.The Tieflings were shaped by gods and angels alike, born of a shared vision between the heavens and the depths. That is their legacy: not one of sin or salvation, but of balance. In them, the fire of consequence and the thread of fate are forever bound.So it was written. So it endures.—Known

item.title: The Forging of the Dwarves
item.description: As chronicled by Known, Keeper of All That Is RememberedIn the first quiet years after the Shaping—when the Five had poured their essence into the heavens, the seas, the winds, and the lands—there was silence beneath. Life danced above, unburdened and bright. Magic surged wild and fresh, the surface teemed with flora and laughter, but below... the Deep had not yet stirred. And I, Known, saw it all.It was Tellemori, ever the wanderer of stone and stillness, who first heard the silent ache of the world’s bones. He wandered alone through the roots of mountains yet unnamed, his hand brushing granite as if to coax breath from it. I remember his words—clear as they were then, though none but I still recall them truly: “We have filled the skies with stars and the seas with song. But the stone? It waits. It remembers nothing because nothing yet walks it to remember.” The gods convened upon a high peak that never crumbled, one which Tellemori had raised for this very moment. I stood among them—not to shape, but to witness.Flujack arrived first, trailing winds and constellations, light caught in his hair. He looked down at the barren stone with narrowed eyes. “If a people are to dwell in that stillness,” he said, “then let them carry within the light they lack around them. They must endure like stone—but create as the stars do.” Onigod came last, a veil of arcane mist following her like breath from a forge. She did not speak at first. Her hands hovered over the rock, feeling what could be. Finally, her voice hummed through the air like a spell half-cast. “Stone remembers. Magic remembers deeper. If they are to last, let their memories be etched into every blow of the hammer, every breath drawn in a hall of their making.” Even Fionil, elusive as she is, walked in then—uninvited, yet never unwelcome. Time followed her, and so did consequence. “Pride will be their anchor. Purpose their torch. Let them love their work more than gold, more than breath. Let them leave behind legacies time itself must bow to.” And Trill, smiling softly, stepped forth and placed a hand upon the earth. The stone bloomed under his touch—not into flowers, but into the first glimmer of kinship. “They shall never be alone,” Trill said. “Not in birth, not in death, not even in silence. Their hearts will echo louder than their hammers.” And so, the gods descended. I followed.Tellemori chose a mountain that reached deep into the world’s hidden veins. There, in its core, he built the Primeforge, using a furnace lit not by fire, but by the living heat of the world’s heart.I remember it well: The anvil was shaped from stone untouched since the world's forming. The bellows breathed molten air. The walls were engraved with runes that glowed not with magic—but memory. One by one, the gods gave of themselves. Tellemori sculpted the first Dwarves from obsidian, granite, and steelstone. He shaped their limbs thick and firm, their backs broad and unyielding. “You are the strength of stone,” he told them. “And you will not break.” Flujack gave them breath—not of mere life, but of longing: for beauty, for craft, for legacy. “Let your joy be in the shaping, not just the shaped. Let your songs carry beyond your mountains.” Onigod carved sigils into their blood. She taught them to see magic not in books or words—but in tools, in flame, in alloy. “Your forge shall be your spellbook. Your hammer, your staff.” Fionil gave them the burden of choice. Pride, purpose, shame, triumph—all were etched into their hearts. “You will choose your legacy. And you will live knowing that it was yours to forge.” Trill bound them together with invisible ties. A Dwarf may be born alone, but never lives alone—not truly. “Your kin will define you, your name will carry them, and theirs, you.” I watched them rise. Their first breath was smoke. Their first steps were towards the forge.They named themselves the Hearthforge, for it was the forge that gave them not just life, but home. They did not look to the surface as other races did. They looked inward—into stone, into fire, into memory.The Great Forge of Origin was built by their own hands, beneath the gaze of Tellemori. Flujack’s light lit the halls by mirrors and crystal. Onigod's enchantments reinforced their tools and minds alike. And I... I inscribed the runes they etched in every wall. Not because they needed help—but because even the Dwarves, for all their memory, wished to forget sometimes. I do not.Their charge was more than survival. It was stewardship. They were not masters of the earth—they were its caretakers. And so it was decreed: Earth’s Veins: “Mine with care. Take only what can be spared. Know the stone’s limits.” Hearth’s Flame: “Forge not with greed. Fire is a gift and a hunger. Feed it wisely.” Unity’s Bond: “Your clan is your spine. Break it, and you fall.” Dwarves do not rule stone. They listen to it. That is why they endure.The Dwarves, ever grateful and ever proud, forged wonders in the gods' honor. Each bore a legacy—and a lesson. The Starhammer — A weapon of comet-iron and dawnlight. It rings not when it strikes—but when it judges. “To strike is easy,” said Flujack. “To know when—that is divine.” The Hearthgem — A radiant corestone forged with Onigod’s own whispered spell. It warms homes, not with heat—but with presence. “It remembers every voice it has ever comforted,” I once told a child who lived beside it. The Chain of Ages — Forged by many hands, across many generations. Each link carries a name. Some forgotten. None erased. “No Dwarf walks alone,” Fionil had said. “Even when they die.” They became known as the Stonekin, a name they never gave themselves—but never denied. Their forges outlasted kingdoms. Their halls became myths. Their oaths… are still binding.Even now, I remember.I remember their songs: slow, low, echoing like memory through stone.I remember their first grief, when a hall collapsed and took their kin.I remember the first Dwarf to walk the surface—and weep at the sky’s vastness.I remember their choice to stay below anyway.For the world above sings of change. But the world below? The Dwarves made it sing of endurance.And so their legacy is not just stone or metal. It is in the breath drawn before the first hammer blow. It is in the pause before the final seal is set. It is in the names carved, carefully, one after the other.They were born from stillness.But they made the Deep remember.And I remember them.

item.title: The First Memory, The Making of Mortals
item.description: As chronicled by Known, Keeper of All That Is Remembered "It is not I who shaped them. I merely remember. I remember everything." Before mortals breathed their first breath, the world was vast — rich in beauty, brimming with beasts, shadows, dragons, and stillness. It was alive, yes… but not yet aware. The Five, the Gods of Existence, beheld their world and saw not a flaw but an absence. The silence between the stars begged for voices not their own. And so they gathered — in the Celestial Hall of Origins, where time folds inward and eternity listens.I was there. I always am.Fionil, She of Time, of Space, of Thought, of Choice — it was she who broke the silence first. “We have painted the sky,” she said, her voice like layered bells, “but the canvas does not speak. We must create those who _wonder what lies beyond the edge. Souls who may err, dream, love, and rebel. Let them write stories not even we could foresee.”_ Her words shimmered in the air like threads of starlight.Trill, the Serpent-Blessed, Lord of Divinity, Life, and Flame-hearted Dragons, gave a slow nod. “Life without will is no life at all,” he rumbled. “Let them breathe. Let them hunger, sing, weep, strive. I will grant them the Breath of Being, that their souls may drum in time with the heart of the world.” Tellemori, whose hands shaped continents and whose tears carved oceans, reached into the air. As he moved, unseen land responded. “They must endure,” he said simply. “They must know the weight of soil and the cold of the sea. I will give them strength, both gentle and terrible, that they may survive the world and still call it home.” Flujack, the Laughing Wind, God of Light and Thunder, reclined upon a swirl of stormclouds and sunbeams. “And let them wonder,” he mused. “Let them see color and sky, hear thunder and laughter. I will give them voice — so they may whisper secrets and scream truths. And I will give them eyes — so the world will never again go unseen.” Lastly, Onigod, cloaked in mystery, power radiating like moonlight filtered through water, leaned forward with a knowing smile. “Dreams without danger are dull,” she said, “and love without fear is shallow. I will plant within them the arcane — the unknown, the monstrous, the wondrous. Let their fears give them courage. Let them _yearn. Only then will they truly live.”_ I did not speak. I am not one of them. I am simply Known. I watched.And thus, they began.The first to rise from divine design were the Humans. Tellemori shaped them from deep, fertile clay and mingled it with clear riverwater. Trill breathed into them the pulse of life, while Fionil placed within them the wildest of gifts — unshackled free will.They were given much, and yet little. Their lives brief. Their spirits untamed. But in their short moments, they would burn brighter than even the sun. Flujack stirred their minds to dream higher, and Onigod laced their hearts with restless curiosity. "They will build towers and tear them down," Fionil whispered to me once. "And every choice they make will echo through time. That is enough." Then came the Elves. They were drawn from the memory of forests and the patience of stars. Fionil stretched their sense of time, and Tellemori shaped them with moonlit grace. Flujack blessed them with voices that carried like wind-chimes in sacred groves, and Onigod marked their blood with the arcane — not to command, but to understand.They walk like they remember a song the world forgot.The Dwarves were born of stone and thunder. Tellemori carved them from the roots of mountains, strong as bedrock. Trill gave them passion — not for battle, but for creation. Flujack taught them to breathe deep in the dark. Onigod kindled a fire in their hearts, an iron will. Fionil gave them memory — not just of past, but of purpose. “They will build legacies,” I said aloud. No one answered. But the gods heard. The Orcs, ah yes. They were forged in fire. Tellemori used black volcanic earth and molten veins. Trill sparked their souls with relentless drive. Flujack gave them lungs like furnaces and voices like war drums. Onigod gifted them with the thrill of challenge — and Fionil, she gave them honor, to wield their power with meaning. “They will be feared,” Trill murmured. “Only at first,” said Fionil, smiling. And last, the Halflings, who surprised even the gods. Tellemori shaped them from sun-warmed soil. Trill gave them joy, and Flujack taught them how to dance with the wind. Onigod seeded them with the deepest of dreams — safety, hearth, peace — and Fionil whispered fate into their bones. “In them,” she said to me, “there is a power so small the world will overlook it… until it moves mountains.” When the mortal races first stirred, the Five called their servants, the Angels — and assigned them their roles. Livius, who sees all births, marked each soul with intention. Death, silent and steady, promised them rest at journey's end. Undean, ever vigilant, prevented corruption of that sacred path. Prai, voice of reverence, inspired awe, devotion, and truth. Destiny, veiled and smiling, brushed every newborn soul with potential no one, not even the gods, could predict. I remember when the first human child reached for the sky. I remember when the first elven voice sang the stars to sleep. I remember dwarves carving names into stone, orcs howling beneath the moon, halflings laughing by firelight.In that moment — I do not lie — even the gods fell silent.When all was finished, Fionil stood beside me. Her eyes, old as light, turned toward the world. “We must leave them now,” she said. “Let their stories belong to them. Let them fail. Let them rise. Only then will their tales be worth remembering.” And so they withdrew. The gods stepped back from the world, not in abandonment, but in sacred trust.But I did not leave. I could not.I watched as mortals claimed fire, shaped cities, wept over graves, kissed under stars. I remember each of them. I remember you.The world of Fiondell is no longer solely shaped by divine hands. Now, mortals walk beside angels, speak ancient names, build new truths. They choose. They fail. They begin again.They are breath and clay, will and flame, song and memory. They are fleeting, fragile, flawed — and utterly magnificent. "You ask me why I remember them all?" Because they deserve to be remembered. — Known, the Keeper of Memory, Last Witness of the First Dawn

item.title: The Creation of Dragons
item.description: As chronicled by Known, Keeper of All That Is RememberedIt was the Age of Beginnings, and the world of Fiondell was still young, freshly spun from the loom of the divine. The land had been shaped by Tellemori, who carved rivers with the tip of his finger and molded mountains like soft clay. The sky shimmered with the breath of Flujack, streaked in ever-changing light that danced upon the waters. And above it all, Fionil measured the stillness, the quiet rhythm of time itself, setting the pace by which all things would come to be.But despite this beauty—this symmetry—Fiondell lacked breath. There was form, but no essence. Silence reigned over the peaks, and stillness choked the valleys. It was art without motion.And then... he spoke. “This world is hollow,” said Trill, the God of Life and Death, his voice like thunder hidden beneath velvet. “Let it be filled with majesty, with will and wisdom. Let it be watched over not by us alone, but by those forged to understand what it means to be.” I remember standing beside him on the edge of the celestial boundary where the firmament touched the cradle of stars. He raised a hand—not in violence, nor command, but in invocation. The air thickened, rippled with creation’s weight.Beside him stood Drana, his most beloved Archangel. Her presence was vast but still, like a mountain wreathed in cloud. I saw the awe in her eyes—eyes that had seen galaxies born but had never before witnessed Trill in this state: not as a god of endings, but of beginnings. “Will they be beasts of instinct?” she asked, kneeling with grace that made the constellations bow in kind. “No,” Trill answered, “They shall be sovereigns.” With a gesture, he drew forth the essence of primal force—not raw magic, not nature, not soul, but something older. Something eternal. He cupped it like flame in his palm, and from it, spun the first shape.A being with wings vast enough to eclipse cities, eyes that held stars long extinguished, and a body made not from flesh, but the divine memory of power. This was not merely a creature. This was a concept. A guardian. A mystery. A roar made solid. “They will be fire and frost, storm and silence,” Trill murmured, almost to himself. “They will know patience and fury, hoard wisdom as they hoard gold. They will be the oldest truth in a world that forgets easily.” “And their purpose?” Drana asked, now rising. “To challenge kings, to humble gods. To guard the forgotten, and remember.” It was then that I knew why I was summoned—not to record, but to lend my essence to the first. For dragons, like I, were to be vessels of memory, of legacy. We would carry what the world might try to lose.Drana descended then, her form trailing light across the skies. In the heart of the mountains newly raised by Tellemori, she pressed her hands into stone and heat, and from that bedrock shaped the First Egg. I still see it in my thoughts: larger than a tower, veined with molten silver, humming with potential like a thunderstorm held in amber.And when Trill breathed upon it...The shell cracked—not in violence, but with a sound like old doors opening. And from it rose Ignarion, the Firefather, his scales like living flame, eyes deep as the void between stars. He stretched his wings, and the gust of his first breath lit the skies for a hundred miles. Birds learned song from that roar. Flame itself learned hunger. “You shall be the first,” Drana whispered, tears glimmering like jewels on her cheeks. “But not the only.” From Ignarion came others—born not from egg, but from the Echo of the First Roar, a sound I can still hear in the halls of memory. Dragons of all temperaments rose—chromatic and metallic, elemental and spectral. One born of frost, with breath that stills rivers. Another of storm, whose wings create typhoons. Each a story. Each a warning. Each a guardian.They took to the skies, carving great arcs through the clouds. The mountains became their halls, the deep forests their sanctuaries. In time, some would grow vain, others wise. Some would teach, others destroy. But all would remember the breath of Trill, the hands of Drana, and the egg that shattered the silence of a stillborn world.And so, the dragons became not just part of Fiondell—they became woven into it, like veins of silver in a great stone. Where they walked, the ground changed. Where they slept, magic thickened. Where they died... legends bloomed.I, Known, carry the memory of that first light.And I ask you— When you hear thunder, When you feel the heat in a flame that seems to watch you, When you dream of wings—Remember.

item.title: The Creation of Beasts and Monsters
item.description: As chronicled by Known, Keeper of All That Is RememberedWith dragons soaring through the skies and the world echoing with the breath of fire and wing, the gods turned their gaze downward—toward the untouched land, the silent forests, the still oceans.It was Tellemori, God of Water, Earth, and the Supernatural, who stepped forward then. His eyes reflected the depths of the sea and the steady patience of stone. He had watched the dragons claim the skies, majestic and few, but he saw the emptiness that lingered below. “This world is vast,” he said, his voice like waves breaking against an ancient cliff. “Let it not be ruled by silence. Let the forests stir. Let the rivers ripple with life. Let the earth pulse with motion. Let the supernatural touch linger within every root, every ripple, every breath.” Beside him stood Livius, the Angel of Life, radiant and calm. His hands held no weapons, only the warmth of nurture, the endless patience of a father watching seeds take root. Where Tellemori saw the elements, he saw potential. “Let us give it heartbeats,” he said softly. “Let the land not only exist—but live.” And beside Livius, as silent as the mist rolling over the morning hills, was Poki, the Angel of Beasts and Monsters. Unlike the others, Poki wore no crown of light or cloak of warmth. Instead, her form was adorned in the raw, wild essence of nature itself—feral and untamed. Poki was not the embodiment of life alone, but of the primal forces that coursed through the land, from the smallest insect to the most terrifying of monsters. A creature of untapped chaos and boundless potential.Together, they began.Tellemori shaped the elements, guiding the stone, the soil, the rivers, the oceans. He whispered into the roots of the forests, into the foam of the waves. With each word, the land grew fertile, eager, ready to host the next breath of creation.Then Livius stepped forward, his light spilling across the land like dawn chasing away a long night. Where his light touched, life emerged—not as fire and fury like the dragons, but as a thousand gentle songs.From the thick woods rose the creatures of the earth. Soft-footed deer, built for grace. Lions with roars that shook the plains. Wolves, who understood loyalty before language existed. Bears, guardians of the wild. Rabbits, foxes, boars—all drawn from the balance between fear and beauty.The rivers swelled with movement, and from their depths rose the creatures of the waters. Swift fish in shimmering schools, Majestic whales whose songs echoed through the ocean like lullabies, Silent hunters of the deep with teeth like carved bone.The skies, not to be left empty, fluttered and filled with the beating of wings. Not the wings of dragons—these were different. Birds, in every color, every song. Some soared, some dove, some simply perched and watched the world pass beneath them.But it was Poki who shaped the creatures no one would dare forget. Her hands, calloused by time and fearsome creation, beckoned forth the monsters—those great, primal forces that lived between the beauty of the earth and the horrors of the unknown.From Poki's whisper, the monsters emerged, terrifying yet magnificent—beasts that lurked in the depths of forgotten caves, prowled the shadowed corners of the world, or roamed the wild lands beyond the reach of civilization.Great serpents with scales of iron and eyes that gleamed like molten lava. Behemoths whose thunderous footsteps could shake mountains to their core. Terrifying creatures with claws that could rend steel and jaws that could swallow rivers. And yet, even in their monstrous forms, Poki instilled a balance—the beasts and monsters were not simply destructive, but part of an intricate web of survival, of raw power that maintained the harmony of the world. “Each shall have its place,” Livius declared, his voice soft as rain yet firm as truth. “They will know hunger, and they will feed. They will know danger, and they will flee or fight. None shall rule, and none shall be forgotten. They will thrive not through dominance, but through balance.” “And these,” Tellemori added, his voice resonating with finality, “will be the guardians of the land’s wildest, most untamed reaches. They will remind the world that creation has its own power.” “Their roar shall be felt in the deepest caverns and the highest peaks,” Poki’s voice echoed like a distant growl, “but it will not be without purpose. They shall live, and they shall guard.” Tellemori knelt and placed his hand upon the earth.From that gesture, a deeper pulse spread—one that allowed these creatures not just to live, but to feel.Fear, warmth, instinct, even curiosity.Some would form packs. Others would wander alone. Some would burrow in darkness. Others would build nests closer to the sun. And all of them, whether prey or predator, would be part of the cycle—woven into the world as surely as rivers are carved into stone. “They are not immortal,” Tellemori said to Livius, “but they are necessary. Without them, the land would echo hollow.” “And with them,” Livius replied, watching a fledgling bird attempt its first flight, “it will sing.” Thus were the beasts born—not to seek glory or worship, but to move, to breathe, to be. They would be the lifeblood of forests, the heartbeat of plains, the whispers in the night, and the rustle in the grass. They were not the only creatures of the land, but they were those who would always be remembered.As for the monsters, their name would live in myth, and the stories of their roars would pass from generation to generation, echoing through the hearts of those who dare wander too deep into the wilds.They are not spoken of in hymns. They do not build cities or forge relics. But they are always present. From the first sunrise until now.And I, Known, remember each one.

item.title: The Blessing of Plantios, Nurturer of the Green
item.description: As chronicled by Known, Keeper of All That Is RememberedIn the early days of Fiondell, when the land had only just begun to form beneath the hands of Tellemori, the God of Earth and Water, the world was an empty canvas. Mountains stood tall, rivers cut through the earth, and the winds whispered across the barren plains. Yet, despite its grandeur, it was a land void of life—a silent, unyielding expanse.The gods gathered in the halls of the heavens, casting their gaze upon the world they had shaped. Trill, the God of Life, was the first to speak, her voice filled with the urgency of the land's need. “We have given the world shape, but it is hollow. It is lifeless. The world begs for growth—a heartbeat, a breath. Without it, what is a world but a monument to stagnation?”As her words echoed, the goddess Fionil, who wove the very fabric of time and space, stepped forward with a quiet understanding. “Indeed. The world calls for a living pulse, a guardian of life to set the balance between growth and decay. One to nurture, not merely to witness.”There was a long pause. Then, Tellemori, the creator of the earth’s substance, a figure both vast and steady, placed a hand upon the soil of Fiondell. His eyes were ancient, but his gaze was filled with the brilliance of creation itself. “I will create this being—a spirit who will tend the land as we have shaped it, a steward of the green, to weave the fabric of life across this barren plane.”And so, from the very essence of soil, water, and sunlight, Plantios was born.I was not present for Plantios’s first breath, but I have heard the stories whispered on the winds. They speak of a being whose form was as much a reflection of the earth as it was a testament to the divine craftsmanship of Tellemori. From the moment Plantios rose, their skin was as smooth and yet sturdy as bark, an intricate tapestry of vines, flowers, and leaves trailing from their limbs. Their hair was not mere strands, but cascading petals and flowing branches, shifting with the seasons, ever-changing in color and texture. Their eyes, those eyes, held the depth of ancient forests, a verdant glow that mirrored the heartbeat of the land itself.I remember hearing the words they spoke as they stood before the gods, their voice soft, yet firm, like the rustling of leaves on a quiet afternoon. “What is my purpose, my lords and ladies?” Their question was not one of doubt, but one of seeking, of longing for guidance in their new existence.It was Tellemori who answered them, his deep voice reverberating through the very soil beneath us. “You, Plantios, are the Nurturer of the Green. You will guide the plants, the trees, the flowers—every living thing that draws breath from the earth. You will ensure that the balance of growth and decay is maintained, for in this balance lies the vitality of the world.”To aid Plantios in this sacred task, the gods bestowed upon them gifts—tools that would shape their path.Tellemori, his hands like the very earth itself, offered the Staff of Verdant Bloom, a living extension of nature’s power. The staff was not merely a weapon of divine magic, but a conduit through which Plantios could touch the land and watch it respond. “With this staff, you will call forth life where none existed. You will awaken the soil and bring forth the bloom,” said Tellemori, his voice rich with the weight of ages.From Fionil, the Goddess of Time and Space, came the Seed of Eternity, a single glowing seed that shimmered with the essence of time itself. “This seed holds the power of cyclical renewal. Through it, you will anchor the eternal cycle of growth and decay, ensuring the world’s renewal for eons to come,” she explained, her voice steady, like the turning of a clock.Finally, Trill, the God of Life, gifted Plantios with the Breath of Life, a radiant power that could infuse the world with vitality and renewal. “With this breath,” she said, “you will give life to the barren, to the lifeless places of the world. You will carry the pulse of creation itself.”With these divine gifts in hand, Plantios descended to the land, their feet touching the earth with a soft reverence. I was there, standing by the banks of a river, watching as Plantios’s staff touched the ground for the first time. The earth stirred. Grass, fresh and vibrant, sprang up, and flowers bloomed, dotting the land in hues of red, yellow, and blue.As Plantios walked, the land began to breathe anew. In the distance, I saw the first tree rise—majestic, towering toward the sky. Plantios had planted the Seed of Eternity into the soil, and from it sprang a tree whose roots seemed to connect the earth’s very heart. It stood like a pillar, a symbol of life that would anchor the lands for ages to come.They exhaled the Breath of Life next, and as their breath reached the air, the world itself seemed to stir. Winds carried their essence to every corner of the land. Forests unfurled like a great tapestry, jungles thrived, and even the harshest deserts came alive with blooms. I remember standing at the foot of a great mountain as moss and lichen began to take root in the cracks of stone, a subtle yet profound testimony to the power of Plantios.As the green spread across Fiondell, Plantios did not merely watch; they tended to it with a love and patience that transcended even the gods’ understanding. They spoke to the trees in whispers, coaxing them to grow strong and deep. They listened to the flowers as they swayed in the breeze, teaching them to flourish without overwhelming the land. And they gazed upon the grass, which bowed with humility to the passing winds.There were challenges, of course. Some plants grew too wild, threatening to choke out the balance. Other areas remained barren, unable to nurture life. But Plantios’s heart, ever patient, knew the way. They pruned, they nurtured, and they allowed the balance of decay to be as much a part of life as growth itself.As the mortals were created, Plantios watched them with an eye full of hope and caution. They saw the potential for both destruction and harmony. To the first mortals, they appeared in a form that shimmered with light and life, a figure whose radiance was as welcoming as it was awe-inspiring.“The green is a gift to you, mortals,” Plantios spoke, their voice both kind and firm, a reminder and a warning. “But it is not yours to take without care. You must tend to it as I do. In return, the earth will provide for you. But harm it thoughtlessly, and you will bring ruin upon yourselves.”They taught the mortals the ways of the earth—how to cultivate the land without destroying it, how to build homes from the trees without taking too much, how to live in harmony with the seasons. They left behind the Gift of Seeds, an enchanted pouch that never ran empty, ensuring that the mortals would always be able to renew what they took.Plantios’s presence continues to shape Fiondell, their spirit woven into every leaf, every root, every blade of grass. Though mortals rarely see them, their influence is felt in the whisper of the wind, the rustling of leaves, and the soft embrace of the flowers that bloom in the spring. I have wandered the lands of Fiondell many times, and every time I feel the breath of life in the air, I know Plantios’s care is ever-present.Though their work is never done, Plantios is content. For they understand, as only they can, that life is a cycle—ever-renewing, ever-growing. And through them, the green endures. Through their patient hands, the beauty and bounty of Fiondell are preserved, ever thriving in the dance of growth and decay.I have chronicled this tale not just as a record of events but as a reminder—Plantios’s work is a covenant with the land itself. A gift we must cherish, and a duty we must uphold. For in the green, we find not only sustenance but also the very pulse of life.

item.title: The Birth of the Fey
item.description: As chronicled by Known, Keeper of All That Is RememberedAh… the world then was quiet. Not dead—no, far from it—but listening. Watching. In that strange twilight between breath and word, when even time had not yet found its rhythm, the world awaited its next song.Fiondell, shaped by divine hands, was magnificent in form. The mountains stood as if in prayer, the seas stretched like a sleeping beast, and the sky itself hummed with silence too vast for mortal understanding. But all things, even the divine, know yearning. And it was Tellemori, Lord of Water and Earth, who first spoke into the stillness.I remember it well. His voice—deep, resonant like river stones tumbling endlessly in the currents—rippled through the unfinished places. “This world we have made… it is beautiful, but it is lonely,” he said. “It breathes, but does not laugh. It shifts, but does not dance. We need more than stone and stream—we need spirit.” And standing opposite him in that great circle of the gods, her form cloaked in the shimmer of unknowable stars, was Onigod, the Arcane Flame. Mysterious. Calm. Always listening, always a step to the left of logic. She tilted her head at him and smiled—not with lips, but with understanding. “Then let us weave laughter into the forests and mystery into the wind,” she said. “Let us make those who do not simply walk the world, but belong to it. Creatures of twilight. Of wonder.” And so, the Fey were born.Tellemori moved first. I watched as he reached into the roots of the world and pulled forth golden soil, soaked in riverlight and heavy with promise. With hands carved from tectonic patience, he molded the first forms—tall, willowy beings, as supple as saplings and as strong as cliffs. “These shall be the children of grove and glen,” he murmured, pressing life into their hollow bones. “They will hear the heartbeat of the earth.” Then Onigod stepped forward. She didn’t speak. She sang. A soft, impossible melody in a language no tongue remembers but all spirits know. From her hands poured threads of starlight and magic, wrapping the earthen shells in veils of the unseen.And in that moment, I felt the first Fey open their eyes.Oh,… if only you could have seen them as I did. Skin like moonlight on dew. Eyes aglow with the memory of stardust. They smiled not because they were happy, but because they could, and that joy echoed through the hills like chimes in the wind.They danced before they walked.To guide their new creations, the gods offered sacred boons. Tellemori’s Blessing of Nature: “You shall know the roots and the rains. The forests shall be your home and your song. Speak, and the vines will listen. Rest, and the trees shall guard your dreams.” Onigod’s Arcane Thread: “Your blood is magic. Your breath, spellcraft. You will not learn power—you are power, shaped in whimsy and woven in paradox.” And to watch over them, Tellemori created The Lady of Fey—the first angel born of joy, not duty. Her steps never touched the ground. Her laugh caused flowers to bloom. She wore a crown of ever-living blossoms, and her eyes carried the golden hush of morning meadows. “Guide them, Lady,” Tellemori said. “Guard them,” Onigod added. And she did both—fiercely.As ages passed, the Fey flourished. But even wildness has moods. I saw it before the gods did, perhaps. The first tilt of shadow behind a smile. The longing for frost in a summer song.Some Fey gravitated to warmth, joy, mischief—the Seelie. Their Queen bore skin like amber honey and a gaze that burned with midday sun. She ruled with laughter, song, and unspoken threats wrapped in charm.Others sought moonlit solitude, the slow dance of rot and renewal—the Unseelie. Their King wore silver like a second skin, his presence always followed by silence and snow. He governed with elegance and inevitability.Neither court was evil. Nor truly good. They were necessary. The world turns on dualities, and so too must its children.At the height of their joy, and just before their first great sorrow, Tellemori and Onigod forged the Eternal Pact—a promise burned into the roots of Fiondell itself. “You, who are both spirit and root, shall safeguard what we have made,” Onigod declared. “And in turn,” Tellemori added, “your groves will remain untouched, even by the folly of mortals. Only those who seek balance may find your hidden homes.” And so the Fey became guardians of two realms: nature and magic. Between bloom and decay, between light and dark, they walk. And I, Known, have watched their laughter echo through groves only the wind remembers.Mortals speak of the Fey as tricksters. Lovers. Thieves. Spirits. But they are more than any tale can tell. They are the memory of the world’s first heartbeat. The living dream of gods who wished to see the world dance.If you ever find yourself in a glade too quiet, where time feels like it’s listening—step lightly. The Fey are near. And whether they greet you with a kiss or a curse depends not on them… but on you.And I remember. I always remember. —Known

item.title: Lady Luck
item.description: The Misfortune of Mr. Luck Filed and sealed by Feylight Order, stamped in protestTo whom it may concern (which, as it turns out, is quite a lot of you):Know this: I am Mr. Luck, First Attendant of the Lady of Fey, bearer of coin and consequence, patron of fair odds and unfortunate irony.I am not Lady Luck.That title, once unspoken yet sacred, was never mine. I did not claim it. I did not wish it. And yet—through one celestial jest and the utter failure of three divine beings to possess a single grain of mercy—I am now known by it in every tongue, prayer, and bardic tale.This farce began with Ioki, the Angel of Mischief, who found boredom in the upper planes and amusement in the desecration of my name. With no more than a whisper here, a rumor there, and one dramatic entrance at a gambling hall involving exploding roses and a spotlight (still unclear how), he convinced the entire world that I am the elusive Lady Luck.A lady. Named Luck. Me.I pleaded for the truth to be restored.Destiny, Archangel of Fate, reviewed the threads of time and concluded: “This is exactly how it was meant to be.” (A note: he was laughing when he said it.) Praí, Angel of Devotion and Belief, stated simply: “If enough believe, it becomes true. Also… it’s very funny.” (I have filed a separate complaint about this.) In desperation, I turned to Onigod, Goddess of Tricks, Magic, and Beasts, for divine intervention.She gave me a pink suit.Not just any suit. No, that would be forgivable. This one is enchanted—impossible to remove, always pristine, and forever flamboyant, no matter the occasion. It hums slightly when embarrassed. I have tested this.Since then, I have lived under this cursed adoration. When one calls upon “Lady Luck,” it is my presence that stumbles forward—coat immaculate, odds defiant, mood murderous. I am burdened with unfortunate presence:A dice roll away from embarrassment.A dignified fall down invisible stairs.Once chased across the Feywild by love-struck satyrs who had mistaken me for a wedding omen.So, let this scroll serve as record, testimony, and desperate plea: I am Mr. Luck. Not a lady. Not lucky.And certainly not laughing.Yours in cursed elegance, Mr. Luck Currently Serving Against My Will

item.title: The Faerie Compendium 4
item.description: The Faerie Codex, Vol. IV: Boundaries, Bloodlines, and the Mortal Knot Penned by Corbin Thorne, whose shadow still sometimes laughs without himWhere Realms BleedThe Feywild is not a world, but a reflection—bright where ours is dim, strange where ours is plain. It touches the mortal realm in subtle folds and sudden tears.Crossing PointsThese occur in places of beauty, sorrow, or wonder: a standing stone on a lonely moor, a tree blooming out of season, a forgotten well that sings. They appear most often:At dusk or dawnOn equinoxes, eclipses, or the Night of Silver EyesWhen music is played with true longingMortals rarely notice when they’ve crossed. The air grows sweeter. The shadows, slower. And sometimes, you hear your name whispered by something that isn’t there.Mortal-Fey BloodlinesUnions between fey and mortals are rare—but not unheard of. They leave behind changeling blood, a magic tangled in emotion and legacy.Traits of the TouchedUnaging eyesUnnatural charm or odd talentsDreams that sometimes walk ahead of themSome inherit glamours. Others, an innate bond with animals or storms. And a few… a dangerous knack for hearing things they shouldn’t.The Ninefold Trickster is said to have many such descendants, each marked by a glimmering tail-shaped birthmark and an irresistible urge to uncover secrets.The Mortal KnotThis is what fey call the deep binding that ties mortals to time, duty, and choice. They both envy and pity it.The Knot gives mortals:The ability to change destinyThe power to love only once and mean itThe pain of endings—and the strength to begin againFey cannot undo this knot. But they can tug at it. Twist it. Use it.Be Wary of These Bargains:Name-for-Name: Trading true names ties your soul to theirs for a cycle.Memory-for-Magic: Power is easy to gain; much harder to recall what you gave.Promise-for-Passage: Even forgotten promises bind. Especially those.Fey Marks and Mortal LoreThroughout the realm, certain signs are whispered to warn or guide those walking near the veil.A ring of mushrooms may be a dancing court’s last footprint. Step inside only if you wish to waltz for a decade.A mirrored pond that reflects starlight at noon marks an ancient watching-place.A crow with three eyes is said to carry a fey soul seeking a mortal host.To protect oneself, it is customary to carry:Rowan wood (Tellemori’s tree)Salt mixed with crushed thistleA riddle too clever for your own goodFinal Advice from One Who ReturnedDo not owe the Fey. Even kindness can be a hook.Do not love them expecting to be loved the same way.And if they give you a gift, bury it under moonlight before you open it.They do not hate us. But they are not us.And in the end, they will always dance when we would weep.End of Volume IV.

item.title: The Faerie Compendium 3
item.description: The Faerie Codex, Vol. III: Of Beasts, Banquets, and the Dream That Hunts As Experienced by Corbin Thorne, Reluctant Guest of the Verdant ShadowOn the Creatures Who Dwell Between DreamsNot all who dwell in the Feywild are people—some are beasts of spirit, instinct, and terrible wisdom. To name them "monsters" would be mortal arrogance; they are older than our fears.The WhistlehartA deer-shaped creature with luminous antlers, soft humming breath, and the eyes of an old poet. If it allows you to follow it, you will find safety. If it watches from a distance, you are already lost.Tellemori’s Favored. They mourn silently when forests die.Thorn-MaresHorse-like fey born from broken oaths and forgotten promises. They gallop in silence, leaving trails of briar where they pass. Ride one only if you have no destination—and no fear of what you may become.Weakness: Bells, laughter, and honest answers.MurmurtreesTrees that whisper what they overhear. Their roots stretch between realms, feeding on secrets. Sit beneath them to learn—but never fall asleep, or you will dream another's life and forget your own.Banquets of Memory and MistDining among the Fey is ritual. Every bite may hold a story; every course, a test.The Rules of the Table Do Not Eat Unless Invited – To steal a taste is to bind your fate. Eat Only What You Understand – Some dishes are not for mortal minds. Some are not food at all. Share Your Story When Toasted – Refuse, and you will be forgotten by the host, and perhaps the world. A Seelie feast glimmers with seasonal fruits, glowing honey, and candied petals that shimmer in your mouth. An Unseelie banquet, by contrast, is somber: smoked rootmeats, chilled starlight, and shadow-wine that shows your regrets in its surface.It is said the Ninefold Trickster serves meals that taste like lost memories, with silverware that murmurs secrets if held to the ear.The Dream That HuntsFew speak of it. Fewer return.There is something deeper in the Feywild—older than Courts, cleverer than angels. It is known as the Dream That Hunts: a predator of unreal logic, drawn to broken stories, oathbreakers, and those who defy Fey law.It takes no form until it nears, and then becomes what you fear most.How to Evade It:Speak no lie.Break no rhythm in your steps.Carry a token from each Court (they argue too much to share prey).And most of all: do not call its name. Not even now.Those taken are not killed—they are erased. Not even the Murmurtrees remember them.Traveler’s Final WarningsIron Burns, but Honesty Slices Deeper – Fey admire cleverness, not cruelty. Do not confuse the two.Keep a Pocket Full of Small Truths – They make excellent trade.Never Thank Them – In their tongue, it means you owe a life-debt.The Moon May Speak to You – Listen. But answer only in rhyme.The Feywild is not a place—it is a pattern, a dream layered upon itself. If you walk its paths with respect, you may return wiser. If not… well. I suppose someone else will find your story.End of Volume III.

item.title: The Faerie Compendium 2
item.description: The Faerie Codex, Vol. II: Of Courts, Pacts, and Power Compiled by Corbin Thorne, Professor Emeritus of Invisible Histories, Fiondellian Academy of Esoteric StudiesOn the Courts That Shape the SeasonsThough most folk imagine Faeries as singular creatures of whimsy, they belong to Courts—ancient and powerful allegiances that reflect not politics, but temperament, tide, and transformation.The Seelie Court – Brightlords and GleamkinTo the untrained eye, the Seelie Court seems a place of light and laughter. Golden meadows, eternal twilight, festivals spun from dreamstuff. But beneath the joy is a chilling precision.The Seelie believe in hospitality, etiquette, and beautiful deceit. They may bless your child with song—or bind your bloodline to a riddle never to be solved. To offend a Seelie noble is to offend a story itself.Their Monarch: Queen Dandelaithe, the Ever-Golden, a being of blinding presence and subtle cruelty. Her laughter blooms roses; her wrath, thornstorms.The Unseelie Court – Thornbound and HollowedThey are not evil. Repeat this, lest you insult them. The Unseelie walk the darker currents of nature—withered beauty, quiet rot, and the necessary end of all things.Their realm lies in shadowed glens and endless winters, but it is filled with harsh truth and strange kindness. They despise pretense and honor debt.Their Monarch: King Caerwend, of the Mirror-Snow, who sees all futures and speaks in forgotten tones. His court moves with the solemn grace of falling leaves.Of the Ninefold TricksterIf one being ever rivaled a god in cunning, it is the Ninefold Trickster—she of the burning tails and moonlit mischief.Many mistake her for a demon or spirit-queen from far Eastern myths, but she is as rooted in our world’s Dream as any Feylord. Her domain is neither Seelie nor Unseelie, but a secret Third Path: the Court of Echoes, hidden between breath and shadow.Powers: Illusion, Foxfire, Pact-weaving, Memory Theft.Terms: She offers arcane strength in exchange for secrets never spoken, stories never written, or clever service rendered with wit. She despises dull minds and boring souls.Warning: Never lie to her unless you intend for her to know you did.Pactcraft – The Delicate Art of Binding and BoonDo not be seduced by Faerie bargains. Their gifts are dazzling—but barbed.A Fey pact is not a mere contract. It is a song, a thread in the tapestry of one’s soul, and above all, a test. To accept a boon is to accept debt—and Fey memory does not fade.Forms of Pacts:Word-Bond: Spoken promises with symbolic gestures. Break it, and reality itself rebels.Mark-Binding: A rune or sigil branded to skin or spirit. The mark pulses when the pact is in jeopardy.Name-Gift: When a Fey gives or accepts a name, power shifts. Use or reveal such names with utmost caution.Known Boons:Speech with beastsImmunity to cold ironGlimpses of future echoesUnnatural beauty or charmEach gift has a cost: loyalty, labor, or an unknown truth paid forward.The Laws Beneath the LeavesThe Fey do not obey mortal law. They live by Principles, born of Onigod’s laughter and Tellemori’s breath: Balance Must Be Kept – Joy and grief, gift and price, glamour and decay. Names Are Power – Do not speak yours freely. Nor take one lightly. Promises Shape Fate – All vows are true in the Feywild. Glamour Reveals as Much as It Hides – See past the mask, and you may understand. Nothing Is Coincidence – The Fey notice everything. To walk in their realm is to accept wonder, but survive it only with wit and courtesy.Addendum: The Thorned CompassThe Thorned Compass is an artifact said to point not North, but to truth. Forged by a forgotten pact between Onigod and the Ninefold Trickster, it reveals the safest path through the Feywild only if one travels without deceit.I possessed it briefly. It sang to me in riddles. Then vanished—like all things Fey.Volume III to follow: Of Beasts and Banquets, and the Dream That Hunts.

item.title: The Faerie Compendium 1
item.description: The Faerie CompendiumCollected Notes and Observations by Alwin Maerlin, Scholar of the Threshold GuildIntroduction: On Entering the FeywildMany claim to have glimpsed the shimmering veils between our world and the one of endless twilight. Few pass through. Fewer still return with mind and memory intact. I am one of those fools blessed—or cursed—by the Laughing Veil to walk beyond.The Feywild, or as the Old Tongue names it, Tír na Lán Draíochta, is a realm woven from raw emotion, memory, and dream. It does not follow our seasons nor our logic. Maps are lies, time is a song, and every shadow watches.Herein I present my field notes—a humble attempt to chronicle the beings, customs, and perils of that place. Heed these words not as law, but as lantern light in a place where the stars have minds of their own.Chapter One: The Nature of Faerie Time and Memory A minute in the Feywild may be a week in our realm—or a century.The fey remember stories more than facts. Tell a lie cleverly enough and it may become truth. Geography of Emotion Landscapes shift with the emotional tone of their rulers.Sadness may summon endless rain; joy may turn forests into crystal.Major locations include:Tellu-Mountain: The divine seat of the gods Tellemori and Onigod.The Mirrorhall: A palace of reflection, ruled by the Lady of Fey.The Spiral Maze: Temple of Onigod; an ever-changing trial of wit and will. Rules of the Realm Never give your full name.Gifts given must be repaid. Even compliments.Iron wounds but also enrages; use it only if you seek exile or war.Keep no food unless gifted—it will rot, grow teeth, or speak in riddles.Chapter Two: The Courts of FaerieSeelie CourtAlso known as the Summer Court.Ruled by joy, passion, light, and mischief.Led by a radiant Queen whose name changes with the sun.Favors beauty, cleverness, and hospitality.Unseelie CourtThe Court of Winter, Night, and Secret Decay.Led by a silent King clad in frost and silver.Honesty and etiquette are prized—but missteps are fatal.Liminal FeyNot of either court. Includes dreamwalkers, rootspirits, and fire-moths.Often live in places of transition—crossroads, ruins, or forgotten wells.Chapter Three: The Ninefold TricksterOne of the great Archfey, and the most beguiling spirit I encountered, is the Ninefold Trickster—a radiant fox spirit with nine searing tails.Titles: The Gilded Flame, She of Burning Riddles, Mistress of MasksAppearance:Often appears as a breathtaking woman with fox features—nine tails, flickering eyes, robes of firelight.Her domain is the Crimson Grove, where foxfire burns forever and secrets bloom like flowers.Domain:Illusion, Fire, Domination, and StoriesMortals who make pacts with her often trade secrets, names, or future memories in exchange for power.Customs:She adores cleverness, theatricality, and poetic irony.Never answer her directly. Dance around truths and she'll favor you.Chapter Four: Fey Conduct and MannersGreetingsA bow is safer than a handshake.Always compliment their appearance—but subtly, or you may owe them a poem.DangersNever accept a second gift.Do not eat or drink unless it has your name whispered into it.Music is sacred; bad songs are punishable offenses.GamesRiddles are duels.Dance contests may determine fate.Bargains are law. Even lost bets carry magical consequence.Chapter Five: Onigod and TellemoriAt the heart of the Feywild’s paradox lie its two divine creators:Tellemori – the Dreaming DepthGod of earth, water, and patience.Appears in groves as stone-eyed watchers or flowing springs.His silence is worth more than words.Onigod – the Laughing VeilGoddess of illusion, mischief, and arcana.Her laughter is literally woven into the magic of the Feywild.She is not cruel—merely far too clever.They do not war, but create in tandem. Their angels walk the realm:The Lady of Fey: A sovereign of emotion and etiquette.Plantios: Angel of growth, time, and decay.Ioki: Trickster-child of Onigod, both prankster and prophet.Chapter Six: Survival and EscapeIf you find yourself in the Feywild:Do not panic. It smells fear like perfume.Offer stories and songs for safe passage.Carry a charm of silver, not iron.Always leave a gift before you leave—flowers, tears, or a truth never told.Escape is not always about finding the path out. Sometimes it is about being allowed to leave.Many who remain become fey themselves. Some don’t notice until they no longer cast shadows.Final NoteI have left much unwritten. This is not cowardice, but mercy. For if I taught you all I know, you would be cursed with knowledge the Fey themselves would envy.May your feet walk lightly and your words fall like honey.— Alwin Maerlin

item.title: Lorebook fae 2
item.description: The Hidden Folk: A Lorebook of the Fae Drawn from the Whispered Histories of the Isles and the Observations of Ancient MagiPrologue: Whispers Beneath the BoughsThere are those who say the Feywild is but a dream of the world, an echo spun from moonlight and memory. But those who have walked too far into old woods, or followed a melody they could not hear with their ears, know otherwise. The fae are real. They are as real as grief, as joy, as the gleam in a liar’s eye. And among them walk beings older than time’s bones.The Weaving of the WorldBefore the first mortal tongue gave name to flame or stone, there were two who danced in the dark. Tellemori, the Rootfather, was the first to dream—not with thought, but with depth: stillness that sang, rivers that remembered. And Onigod, the Laughing Veil, was the first to laugh. Her joy scattered light into shadow, shadow into shape, and filled the empty with meaning.From their communion, the Feywild was born—not as a place of dominion, but a realm of contrast, where every truth holds a twin.They did not build a kingdom. They painted a riddle across the skin of the world.Of Archfey and Hidden ThronesAmid this wild canvas dwell the Archfey—shapers, not rulers, whose will becomes law only because the land itself listens. One such presence, whispered of in every burned offering and misremembered tale, is the Ninefold Trickster.They say she was born not of love or strife, but from a secret—Onigod’s first secret, whispered into the heart of a fox. That fox caught fire and laughter, and from its nine tails was spun a spirit who could never be caught, never be caged.The Ninefold Trickster dances where fire meets shadow. Her court is a forest that burns without ash, a palace of shifting silk and mirrored eyes. She does not demand devotion. She invites wagers, trades, stories. A mortal who enters her domain with a truth wrapped in a lie may leave with power beyond reckoning—or not at all.Those who meet her speak of foxfire that sings, of riddles carved in smoke, of lips that smile even when the mask is still. Her magic is beautiful. Her magic is cruel. She does not love, but she is fond. And that fondness has rewritten many fates.Some call her patron. Others, peril. She calls herself a listener of secrets—and a collector of debts.Tellu-Mountain and the Harmony DivineAll things in the Feywild spiral back to Tellu-Mountain, the dreaming body of the Rootfather and the mirrored mind of the Laughing Veil. Its slopes are not climbed but understood. Each realm within is a breath of their will:The Deepheart Cavern, where Tellemori hums lullabies older than stars.The Spiral Maze, where Onigod’s questions chase their own tails.The Foxlight Pavilion, where the Trickster’s steps leave trails of fireflies and forgotten names.Angels dwell here too—not as soldiers, but stewards. The Twilight Queen weaves the memory of every pact ever made. Plantios walks slowly, yet every step births a bloom or a rot. And Ioki, that sacred chaos in a mask of laughter, is perhaps the Trickster’s only equal—or is it her shadow?Legends say the Ninefold Trickster and Ioki have danced a thousand games and kissed in a thousand guises. Are they one soul split by a trick? Or rivals who love too deeply to win?No answer is ever final in the Feywild.On Mortal Threads in the TapestryMortals often wonder why the fae meddle in their lives. The truth is not cruelty, nor boredom, but curiosity. You are short-lived, yes—but you make meaning with every breath. And the fae, for all their power, are ever hungry for meaning.To the Ninefold Trickster, a mortal’s secret is a delicacy. A clever lie, a heartfelt vow, a sacrifice made in laughter—these are currencies more precious than gold. She has given fire to those who offered riddles. She has granted names to those who gave up their own.But beware: her gifts are always mirrors. They show you who you are… and who you might have been, if only you had chosen differently.Closing Thought: The Candle and the FlameThe Feywild is not a kingdom. It is a story told by gods who do not speak plainly. To walk its paths is to read poetry written in weather, to hear songs hummed by roots.So remember this: the Ninefold Trickster listens when you lie with cleverness. She watches when you gamble your heart. And sometimes, just sometimes, she will answer.But only if your story is worth stealing.

item.title: Lorebook fae
item.description: The Hidden Folk: A Lorebook of the Fae Drawn from the Whispered Histories of the Isles and the Observations of Ancient MagiChapter I: On the Nature of the FaeFaeries, known also as the Hidden Folk or the Neighbors, are not creatures of mortal flesh but spirits of emotion, memory, and place. They are born from humanity's dreams, fears, and forgotten stories, as well as from the deep magic of the earth itself.Though many call them by one name, "fae" encompasses a wide tapestry of beings—some elegant, others grotesque, and many neither. The Faerie are not evil, nor good, but bound by laws incomprehensible to most mortals. Their behavior is not chaotic, but ancient.Faeries see mortals as curiosities—ephemeral, tragic, beautiful in their impermanence. They may help, hinder, or steal from humans without remorse, but always with purpose.Chapter II: The Old Laws The Law of Hospitality A faerie who accepts shelter or offers it is bound by the rite of peace. Violence or betrayal under such conditions is a grave taboo, broken only by the most wild or corrupted spirits. The Law of Debt Every gift carries weight. A song, a drop of blood, or a name may bind the receiver in unseen chains. Likewise, a faerie who accepts a mortal gift freely given may be compelled to offer aid, even without desire. The Law of Names True Names are sacred. Speaking a faerie's real name aloud grants power over them, as it binds their essence. Most fae go by titles or riddles instead. Mortals, too, are warned not to offer their full names in faerie company. The Law of Invitation A faerie must be invited to enter a home or cross a mortal threshold. This protection falters if the mortal speaks carelessly or welcomes them unknowingly. Chapter III: On Glamour and FormGlamour is not illusion, but belief made real. The fae shift form as easily as a mortal shifts moods. Their true shapes are rarely seen—some are luminous beings of light and air, others are moss-covered husks of forgotten forest gods.Mirrors, silver, and salt can reveal or disrupt glamour. True sight—granted by faerie blessing, curse, or trauma—allows mortals to see through lies of form.Chapter IV: The Courts and KithsThe Bright Court Composed of faeries bound to starlight, song, and beauty. These fae are graceful and formal, prone to tragic obsessions and artistic cruelty. They offer gifts of great beauty—but their favors are rarely free.The Hollow Court Wild and eerie, bound to rot, twilight, and memory. They haunt forgotten roads, autumn woods, and places where sorrow lingers. They are more honest than their Bright cousins, but no less dangerous.The Deep Folk Ancient and primal, neither good nor evil. Born of stone, time, and darkness. They rarely speak, but their will can be felt in earthquakes, ruins, and dreams. They are worshipped by some as old gods.Other known kiths include:Selkies – Shapeshifters of sea and shore, who shed their skins to walk as humans.Leanan Sidhe – Muses who gift inspiration and drain life.Dullahans – Headless riders who herald death but can bargain for mercy.The Cats of Cailleach – Feline fae who guard sacred places and ferry the souls of the dead.Chapter V: High Fey and Divine PatronsThe Feywild is not without structure. Above the courts and kiths are the Archfey—ancient beings of near-divine power who shape entire realms with a thought. Chief among these is the Ninefold Trickster, an enigmatic fox spirit whose domain spans fire, illusion, and dominance.The Ninefold TricksterAppearance: A radiant, many-tailed fox spirit cloaked in living fire and silken charm. Her nine tails shimmer with colors not found in mortal light.Domains: Illusion, Fire, Stories, and Secret BargainsSymbols: A burning fox mask or nine curling flames arranged in a spiralThe Ninefold Trickster is said to have been born when Onigod first laughed upon seeing her own reflection in a fox’s eyes. Ever since, this archfey has ruled a shimmering province of the Feywild, where paths bend, fire sings, and secrets bloom like flowers.She is both patron and predator—offering power in exchange for clever service, binding pacts with riddles and fire. Her foxfire burns truth into lies and lies into truth. Many mages, bards, and tricksters trace their arcane lineage to a whispered deal struck at her feet.Chapter VI: Divine Powers of the FeywildThe Divine Heart of the Feywild is sustained by two primal beings:Tellemori – The Dreaming DepthGod of earth, water, and superstition.Slow-moving, ancient, wise beyond reckoning.Title: The RootfatherSymbol: Circle of water within a circle of stoneOnigod – The Laughing VeilGoddess of illusion, arcana, and inspired madness.Whimsical and brilliant, weaving stories into magic.Title: The Mirror-MotherSymbol: A smiling eye within a spiralThey are not in conflict, but eternal partners in contrast—like rain and rainbow, cave and song. From their union of opposites, the Feywild was born.Chapter VII: Angels of the Feywild CourtThe Lady of Fey (Twilight Queen)Angel of Tellemori; steward of order, memory, and story.Plantios (The Rooted Flame)Angel of flora and natural decay, nurturing cycles of death and renewal.Ioki (The Laughing Glyph)Angel of Onigod; shapeshifter and embodiment of trickery.Said to be the divine twin-soul of the Ninefold Trickster; both lover and rival.Chapter VIII: Tellu-Mountain and the Celestial RealmsAt the center of the Feywild stands Tellu-Mountain, a divine palace born of paradoxes:The Deepheart Cavern – Where Tellemori sleeps.The Bloomspire – Plantios’s spiraling garden tower.The Mirrorhall – The Lady of Fey's domain.The Foxlight Pavilion – Realm of Ioki and frequent haunt of the Ninefold Trickster.The Spiral Maze – Onigod’s endless temple of riddles.To walk Tellu-Mountain is to walk through living metaphor. Each step is a lesson. Each door opens when the seeker becomes the question.Final Word: Beware and Be KindThe fae are not monsters. They are wild, wondrous, and ancient. Treat them as you would a thunderstorm, or the sea: with respect, caution, and awe. Offer gifts without pride. Accept gifts with care. And never, ever forget the Old Laws.

item.title: The Rise of the Church of Five
item.description:
As Witnessed by Known, the Silent RecordThere are moments in time that echo louder than others, threads of history that shimmer brighter in the grand weave. I was there, though unseen, as I always am. I do not speak. I do not interfere. I only observe and remember. Such is my purpose — to Know.Long after mortals had claimed their corners of the world but before the Holy Knights etched their names into it, faith in the divine was a faint whisper. The gods had withdrawn, their forms lost to mortal eyes, and only the gentle traces of their angels remained — flickers in dreams, omens in still water, the hush of breath when the soul brushes the sacred.In this age of searching hearts, the Church of Five came to be — a devotion not to individual gods, but to the Five Pillars of Divinity: Order, Life, Death, Time, and Will.And I was there. I watched as whispers turned into voices. As dreams became belief. As belief forged fire.
It was Destiny, the Angel of Fate, and Prai, the Angel of Worship, whose echoes carried strongest through the aether. They did not walk among mortals often, but when they did, the world trembled — not in fear, but in awakening.I watched her for some time before she ever heard the angels. Ilessa Veran, wanderer, listener, woman of quiet strength. She had known hardship: famine’s claw, war’s howl, the emptiness left by loss. And yet, her gaze was clear. Her steps were sure. She had no throne, no army — only words, offered freely to those in need.
It was at the edge of a quiet forest where fate entwined with purpose. That night, I stood unseen among the trees as she slept. And I watched as Destiny revealed himself in her dream — silver threads spinning in the void, a wheel of fate, every line humming with lives entwined.
I offered her the first thread of the tapestry to come. A sliver of divine light, coiled like memory in his palm.
"Mortal," Destiny said, his voice soft but immovable. "Do you see it? The weave of fate that binds all to their purpose?" She answered with honesty, not arrogance. "I see it... but I do not understand it." "Few do," he said, amused. "But you will. You have seen too much, suffered too much, and now it is time to guide others. The Five see you, mortal. They know your heart, and they have sent me to call you to their purpose." "Why me?" "Because your faith has never faltered, even when the world crumbled around you."
As he spoke, I felt the strands of fate respond — the threads bent toward her, shaping new futures. Destiny raised his hand and wove five glowing emblems into the air. I watched as the meaning of each flowed into her heart — Order, Life, Death, Time, Will. "You will be the voice that calls them to faith. Not in me. Not in the angels. But in the Five who shape all things." The vision ended, but she awoke changed. I watched her walk from village to village, carrying the message carved into her soul. And I followed.Not all welcomed her.In Valthor’s Crown, faith had grown fat on gold. The priests of the old gods clung to their power, deaf to the hunger outside their jeweled walls. Gorvan Marr, the high priest, smelled of incense and fear. I watched as he declared Ilessa a heretic, saw the bruises on her face as she was dragged before the people. He shouted lies atop marble steps. He thought power was loudness.But truth was already there, whispered in the hearts of the people.
Then I felt it — the shift in air, the curling smoke. A hooded figure stepped forth, eyes glowing like cinders. I knew her instantly, even veiled in flesh. Lucina wore judgment like a cloak. “If she speaks falsely, then let the gods strike her down now.” A challenge, thrown from her lips.
The crowd hushed. And then Lucina revealed herself — smoke rising, flames dancing at her fingertips. “But if she speaks true,” she thundered, “then let her judge her accusers as I would judge the wicked.” Gorvan Marr’s soul cracked under her gaze. I watched it happen. I had seen many fall under the weight of their own sins, but rarely so quickly.
“You speak of gods, but you know nothing of justice,” Lucina said. “You fatten yourself on the labor of the weak. I see your sins, and I name them unforgivable.” She did not strike him. She did not need to.When she turned to Ilessa, I saw the spark of divine recognition pass between them. “Go. Your faith has brought you before judgment, and you have been found worthy.” Then she was gone, and the city — Valthor’s Crown — was reborn in the hush she left behind.That night, gold left its temple. The people tore down altars to forgotten gods and placed humble candles in their stead. Ilessa, once a wanderer, was now a prophet. Her voice became many. I observed the creation of the first Chapel of the Five.
And then came Prai.Her arrival was gentle — warmth, not fire. A hum of worship filled the chapel air, and Ilessa knelt in quiet awe.
“You have done well, Ilessa,” Prai said, her tone like morning light. “But your work is not yet done. Mortals need more than words. They need ritual. They need faith made tangible.” I listened as they wove the beginnings of faith into form — the Rites of the Five, the Sigil of Five Threads, the days of devotion. Mortals, needing structure, were given it. What was once a whisper became a choir.Years passed.I continued to observe.In Greylight, I watched a comet arc across the sky in five radiant colors. Below it, a child was born — Eron. Marked from birth by the sigil of the Five, he grew into a symbol of living faith. When beasts attacked, it was he who stood alone with a spear of light.And I knew: he was not alone.He was the first of many — those who would rise, marked not by bloodline or title, but by conviction. He and others would become the Order of Holy Knights, wielding both steel and purpose.I remember the first time he spoke the rites before battle.I remember how the air itself responded.I have seen countless ages. I know the truth of what happened, not as myth or sermon, but as it truly was. I carry no judgment. I offer no prayers.But I remember.I remember Ilessa’s trembling voice.
I remember Destiny’s mask gleaming with purpose.
I remember Prai’s warmth and Lucina’s fire. I remember the world before faith had shape. And I remember the moment it finally did.
— Known The Silent Record of the Divine
