item.title: The Banishment of the Voidbringer
item.description:
As remembered by Known
In the primordial days, when Fiondell still pulsed with the fresh breath of creation, I watched from the loom of memory as harmony reigned supreme among the Five. The gods—Fionil, Trill, Onigod, Flujack, and Tellemori—wove existence with confident hands. Yet even their grand design harbored an absence, a silent hollow at the fringes of light. From that abyss emerged Kryxis, the Voidbringer—a hunger given voice.
I first heard Kryxis’s plea echoing through the Celestial Halls like wind through an empty cave. Its words were not thunderous, but a sibilant whisper that made the threadwork of fate tremble: “You shape, you mold, you fill the void with your light. But you have left no place for me. Am I not part of the balance? Shall I be denied purpose?”
I felt the Tapestry shudder under the weight of that question. The Five gathered in the Hall of Threads, its vaulted ceiling a shimmering web of potential futures.
Fionil spoke first, her voice as steady as a clock’s tick:
“Kryxis seeks not harmony, but unmaking. Creation and void cannot both have dominion. We must shield the weave.”
Trill’s solemn tone wavered as he stroked a scale from a crystal drake’s wing:
“And yet… is it wrong to yearn for a purpose? Could we not grant Kryxis a place—a single stitch—so it might learn to uphold rather than erase?”
Onigod’s laughter rippled like magic unbound: “To grant the Voidbringer a thread is to invite ruin. Its very essence corrodes. We cannot gamble the whole Tapestry on hope.”
The gods were at an impasse. So they turned to Destiny, Angel of Fate, the weaver whose courage equals his insight. I stood beside him, silent witness.
Destiny stepped into the center of the Hall. The threads of fate hummed around him. I recall the hush that fell—time itself paused.
“Great ones,” Destiny said, voice resonant, “I offer compromise. Let me weave a single void-thread into the Tapestry. If Kryxis can sustain it—tend it without devouring all—then it may earn its place.”
Fionil’s gaze found his, inscrutable but tinged with hope. At last, she consented: “Do as you will, my son.”
Destiny descended to the Loomhall. Before him lay the tapestry: strands of light, color, life, and possibility. With deliberate care, he plucked a sliver of nothingness from the Outer Expanse and wove it through the golden threads. A black thread appeared—fragile, cold, but stable.
Destiny turned to Kryxis’s shadowed form at the edge of existence: “This is your chance, Voidbringer. Tend this thread. Show us you can coexist.”
Kryxis bowed, its hunger made hopeful promise: “I will not fail.”
For a time, the thread of void held, a mysterious rune woven into the pattern. But void is never content. Kryxis’s hunger grew. I watched in silent dread as the thread unfurled claws of emptiness, clutching neighboring strands.Mortal realms felt it first: harvests rotted in the field, once-brilliant stars winked out, and nightmares took flesh—Wraithborn emerging at the edges of villages, feeding on sorrow.I saw a farmer named Mara, tears streaming as her fields turned to ash. I saw children huddle in lantern-lit cellars, listening to their own hearts pound with terror. And I knew the Tapestry was unraveling.
Fionil’s command rang across the void: “Enough!”
Flujack answered with a tempest: skies rent with lightning so bright it seared the night. His thunderous decree: “You shall not corrupt this world!”
Yet Kryxis’s shroud withstood the storm. Tellemori, earth’s heartbeat, struck next: “By stone and river, I bind you!” He raised mountains to trap the void, poured oceans to drown its spread. But the void seeped through cracks, corrupting all in its path.
In desperation, the Five called their angels. Destiny stood resolute: “This is my burden. I led this gamble; I will end it.” He led a host of angels into the breach:
Clock slowed the unraveling, turning moments backward to sew frayed ends.
Willia inspired mortals, granting them resolve to face encroaching despair.
Arcna, mistress of the arcane, wove binding runes around the void-thread.
Lucina descended in infernal flame, her judgment burning away the worst of the corruption.
Together—Light, Stone, Time, Will, Magic, and Judgment—they drove Kryxis back. Yet the void’s hunger was relentless.
In that dark hour, Destiny made his choice. He turned to Fionil, tears of starlight in his eyes: “Goddess, we cannot destroy the Voidbringer—it is beyond unmaking. But I will bind it beyond all reach. I will sacrifice my place in the Tapestry to seal it in the Endless Expanse.”
Fionil’s sorrow resonated through every thread: “If you do this, you will be sundered from fate itself. The Loomhall will no longer sing your name. You may be lost.”
Destiny’s resolve shone brighter: “The Tapestry is not for me to own. I am its guardian, not its master.”
With the gods’ united power, they wove the final seal—a prison of unbroken light and unyielding time. Kryxis’s howls echoed into the void as it was drawn away, leaving only silence.
The void-thread snapped free, and the Tapestry shuddered as it healed, threads knitting beneath Destiny’s absent hand.I watched the world’s slow recovery. Fields regrew. Stars rekindled. Fearless mortals ventured forth, bearing scars of a darkness they barely understood. From this grim legacy rose the Shadowmarked—those whose veins carried a spark of void, a delicate power born of crisis.
Destiny returned—diminished, perhaps, but unbowed. He no longer wove every thread, but he wandered Fiondell, gently guiding fate with whispered nudges.The gods honored his sacrifice. No trumpet blared; no chorus sang. Even gods speak softly of true miracles. Yet they vowed vigilance—lest the void’s hunger stir again.
And I, Known, have etched every moment into memory. The scars in the night sky—endless dark patches where stars once gleamed—are my silent reminder: balance demands both creation and watchful restraint.
In every age, when threads tremble, I remember Destiny’s choice: Not to claim fate, but to protect it.— Known, Angel of Knowledge and Eternal Witness

item.title: Fiondell
item.description: Fiondell is a world/ planet who is depicted in The tapestry. Fiondell was created by the five gods of creation and is monitored by them and their Angels. Fiondell is the central world of The Tapestry, the grand creation woven by the Five Gods of Creation. Named after Fionil, the goddess of time, space, mind, and order, Fiondell is a vibrant, living world where divine power flows freely and mortal destinies unfold. This is a realm where swords clash, magic pulses, and the presence of gods and angels is deeply felt.The Five Gods fashioned Fiondell as their masterpiece—a world rich with life, conflict, and endless stories. The gods rarely walk openly here, but their angels watch over the lands, guiding, protecting, and sometimes testing those who dwell below. Fiondell is a terrestrial planet with sprawling continents, vast oceans, and a varied climate—from frozen tundras to scorching deserts. Magic is a natural force here, drawn from the weave of the cosmos and influenced by the god Onigod’s arcane design. Mortal cultures vary widely across continents—some embrace magic openly, while others thrive on technology or strict military order. The land itself bears scars of divine influence and ancient conflict: ruins of fallen empires, sacred ley lines, and places where the void’s dark whispers linger. Celestial relics and artifacts of great power are hidden across the world, remnants of the gods’ handiwork and past battles. Fiondell is divided into many continents, each unique in culture, geography, and divine oversight. Some are fully mapped, others remain mysteries, and a few are shrouded in legend.Discovered during the Age of Water by the human prince Demre Brassleaf, Varlen Brassleaf proved the world held more land beyond the familiar seas. Varlen Brassleaf is a continent where swords and magic intertwine. Before humans arrived, it was home to elves, dwarfs, orcs, and halflings. Over time, humans and others migrated here, weaving a diverse and often tense tapestry of races and cultures. The continent’s cities reflect this diversity and history: Demre Stade: Founded and declared an independent kingdom by Stade Brassleaf, son of Demre, at the close of the Age of Water. Elven Forest: Ancient and fiercely protected by elves, the forest has stood since before the Age of Water and remains a place few outsiders enter. Fishy Elifodep: A multicultural city created during the Age of Plants, intended as a haven for all races. Med é Vill: A tribal orc stronghold known for its love of battle, predating the Age of Water. Rapt Orlando: A halfling city famed for its peaceful nature and lack of violence. Tinn Vill: The dwarven city centered on the continent’s only mine, where most dwarfs live beneath the earth. Frostmá: A deadly island overrun by beasts and ruin. Each city venerates its own interpretation of The Tapestry, reflecting the continent’s spiritual diversity. A small, industrial continent shaped by steampunk technology and innovation. Only humans and elves live here, and they deny the existence of magic and other supernatural beings, though they unknowingly channel arcane energies to power their machines and inventions.A remote volcanic island inhabited solely by dragons and isolated dragonborn clans. The island is fiercely protected and governed by Drana, Archangel of Dragons, who also serves as the angel of war due to her fierce temperament.Khorvaire is a land defined by constant conflict, strategy, and power struggles. The primary angels overseeing this continent are Destiny and Drana. Drana’s role as the angel of war deeply influences Khorvaire’s endless battles and volatile politics. Contrary to earlier accounts, Prai has no connection to Khorvaire. Fiondell is more than a world—it is a living stage for the ongoing interplay of divine will, mortal courage, and cosmic mystery. The gods rarely intervene directly but influence the world through angels, relics, and the fates they weave. The Five Gods’ presence is often felt but seldom seen. Angels act as guides, protectors, or challengers for the peoples below. Heroes of Fiondell shape the fate of continents, uncover divine secrets, and battle the creeping darkness left by the Voidbringer. “In Fiondell, every leaf carries a story, every mountain holds a memory, and every soul is a thread in the great Tapestry of existence. The gods weave not only worlds but destinies.” — Known, Angel of Knowledge

item.title: The Void
item.description:
The Void is not a realm in the traditional sense—it is the absence of all realms. It exists not beside the Tapestry, but beneath it, or before it, like a discarded canvas never meant to bear color or form. It is where nothing has ever been, and where nothing ever should be.It is silent, utterly still, and entirely without light, sound, space, or time—yet paradoxically, it exists. The Void is the remnant of the infinite Before, left untouched by the gods when they wove the Tapestry of existence. The Void is not made of shadow, darkness, or death—it is beyond such things. It is absence, the null that mocks creation. It is unreachable by most planar means. Only those touched by void-magic or the Wraithborn curse may even glimpse its borders. No gods dwell here. No light can be summoned, and no soul may linger. It is said that to enter the Void is to lose your name, your shape, and your meaning—becoming something less than nothing. Among the mortal world, a heretical group known as the Void Clan believes that Kryxis, the Voidbringer, is the true heir of the cosmos. They preach that existence is the flaw, and nothingness is the truth. The Void Clan acts in secret, often masquerading as other cults or sages. Their ultimate goal is to fracture the Tapestry, opening enough rifts to allow Kryxis to feed once more. Some seek the Wraithborn transformation, believing it will elevate them to become true voidspawn. At the heart of the Void lies the Endless Expanse—a non-place sealed outside all dimensions. It is not part of the Void, the Tapestry, or the divine realms. It was woven into reality by Destiny, Archangel of Fate, during the War of Unraveling, using his own essence to seal Kryxis beyond the threads of time. The Expanse contains only Kryxis, chained in silence by void-thread runes bound by paradox. The space surrounding the Expanse reacts violently to consciousness—driving minds to madness or stripping them of identity. From here, Kryxis still dreams—and in its dreams, echoes of void seep back into the world through cracks in the weave. Though sealed, Kryxis’ influence lingers. Pockets of unreality—Void Scars—manifest in the mortal world where reality weakens. In these places: Stars vanish, and the sky becomes a blank dome of ink. Memories fade, and the laws of nature begin to unravel. Wraithborn hunt in silence, feeding on meaning itself. These zones are closely watched by angelic wardens and hunted by Fionil's agents, but not all can be cleansed. Some persist, growing like tumors on the Tapestry.The Void stands not as an opposing realm, but as a fundamental counterforce to all that exists. It is not evil—it is apathetic, cold, and incomprehensible. It is not chaos—it is the erasure of all pattern. It is not death—it is the undoing of the soul. The gods do not speak of the Void. Even Fionil, goddess of mind and space, refuses to record its full truth in Known’s Library. “Before there was anything, there was Kryxis. Before breath, before thought. It waits still, in the quiet between the stars.” — Scripture of the Null Tongue, Void Clan Manuscript KryxisKryxis is a primordial entity of pure nothingness, an embodiment of the void that existed before creation. It was not crafted by the Five Gods but born from the empty spaces left untouched in their grand design. Unlike the gods, who shaped and wove existence into the Celestial Tapestry, Kryxis was never given a place, and its very essence was antithetical to creation. Unmaking: Everything Kryxis touches begins to unravel, as its nature is to consume and return all things to void. It does not destroy in the conventional sense—it erases, making it as though something never existed. The Hunger: Kryxis craves a place in existence, but its very being is paradoxical—it cannot create, only consume. This hunger drives it to expand endlessly, devouring reality to make space for itself. Wraithborn: The corruption Kryxis spread during its brief presence in the Tapestry gave birth to the Wraithborn, shadowy entities of despair and emptiness that still haunt the world.
Shadowmarked: Mortals who were exposed to its power became the first Shadowmarked, inheriting a connection to the void that grants them dark powers but tempts them toward oblivion. When Destiny gave Kryxis a single void-thread in the Celestial Tapestry, the Voidbringer failed to contain its hunger and instead began consuming creation itself. This led to a war between the gods and Kryxis, where even divine might struggled against the endless void.
In the final battle, Destiny sacrificed his place among the heavens to weave an unbreakable seal, banishing Kryxis to the Endless Expanse, a realm beyond time and space where its hunger could do no harm. Though Kryxis is imprisoned, its influence lingers in the scars left on the world—dark patches in the sky where stars refuse to shine, and the restless stirrings of the Wraithborn.
Kryxis remains a cosmic horror, an ever-hungry force beyond reality, waiting for the slightest weakness in its prison. Some cultists and warlocks seek to commune with the Voidbringer, believing that through its power, they might reshape reality—or unmake it entirely. Though the gods sealed it away, whispers of the void still echo in the forgotten corners of Fiondell, a reminder that even creation is not immune to the nothingness from which it came.
Holó, Angel of Dematerialization, was created as a part of two where Ari´ce, Angel of Materialization and Holó, Angel of Dematerialization was created by Fionil, the goddess of time, space, mind and order to be her shapers of The tapestry. but Holó, Angel of Dematerialization was tempted by the void and became the angel of Kryxis instead.

item.title: Plane of reflection
item.description: The Plane of Reflection is a realm of pure, endless sky—an infinite expanse of drifting clouds, glistening light, and the soft whispers of the wind. It is timeless and weightless, where stillness reigns and thought echoes. This is the divine realm of Flujack, god of Air, Sky, and Light, and the celestial home of his angels.Though it appears peaceful and without danger, the Plane of Reflection hides great challenges for mortal minds—especially within its most guarded sanctum.The entire plane consists of nothing but air. There is no land, no water, no floor—only boundless sky. Drifting islands of cloud and radiant sunbeams break the monotony, but the space stretches forever in every direction.Suspended in the very center of this void are two structures: the Sanctum of Sky, and the Vault of Stilllight.A majestic, floating palace woven of radiant air, clear crystal, and glimmering light. The Sanctum of Sky is the domain of Flujack and his celestial court of angels. The architecture constantly shifts, bending like wind-blown fabric. Flujack spends most of his time asleep atop a vast bed of cloudfeathers and gentle air currents. His dreams shape the winds and light of the mortal realm. Despite his slumber, his will is powerful, and he communicates through dreams, breezes, and celestial signs. The sanctum is quiet and serene, watched over by his angels, who maintain the delicate balance of air, light, and change. Each angel resides in a chamber reflecting their domain: Sky, Angel of Air – Dwells within whirling vortexes of endless currents. Day, Angel of Light – Resides in a sunlit prism chamber that never dims. Night, Angel of Darkness – Keeps a quiet room filled with false stars and hushed thoughts. Mr. Season, Angel of Seasons – Lives in a rotating chamber of changing weather and flora. Sandman, Angel of Slumber – Dreams eternally in a drifting room of fog and whispering sleep. The second structure, a towering silver spire suspended by nothing, is known as the Vault of Stilllight. It serves two divine purposes: The celestial gateway to and from the Plane of Reflection. A trial of soul and mind, used to guard powerful relics forged by gods and sealed away from the mortal realm. At its summit is a shimmering mirror portal that serves as the only stable path to this plane. Only those chosen or summoned by divine beings may pass.Beneath the gate lies the heart of the Vault—a psychic dungeon unlike any other. This is not a trial of might or magic, but of mind, memory, and soul. Each challenger faces their deepest fears, regrets, shames, failures, and hidden weaknesses, manifested through powerful illusions and divine constructs. The vault is designed not to defeat the body, but to break the spirit. Time may feel endless within its depths, and each room can isolate challengers within their own minds. Those who endure the entire trial are judged worthy, and may claim a divine relic sealed within. These relics are fragments of divine essence—tools too dangerous, too sacred, or too world-shifting to be left unchecked. Many heroes enter. Few emerge whole. But those who succeed often leave changed, bearing celestial artifacts capable of reshaping fate.The Plane of Reflection is the sacred pause between cosmic breaths. It is: A place of divine rest, where air and thought flow freely. A trial of soul, designed to purify and temper mortal ambition. A vault of forgotten power, where the gods store their most perilous creations. It reminds all that true change begins within, and that peace is not the absence of struggle, but the stillness found beyond it.

item.title: Plane of the Gods
item.description: Above all realms, far from mortal suffering, lies the Plane of the Gods—the eternal heaven, a realm of balance, memory, and celestial purpose. It is not a place of conflict or reward, but of origin, intention, and creation. Here, the threads of all reality—the Tapestry—are seen clearly, and all who reside here know their part in its weave.The Tapestry is the eternal weave of existence itself: time, space, matter, emotion, soul, and story. It was born from the gods’ will, shaped by their angels, and colored by the lives of mortals. The Plane of the Gods is the spiritual core of the Tapestry, where all threads converge and are watched over with infinite care.Five gods created the Tapestry and shaped its infinite strands. Of these, Fionil and Trill reside in the Plane of the Gods, maintaining harmony and overseeing the vast workings of existence. Fionil, goddess of Time, Space, Mind, and Order, the highest of the gods. She weaves structure into chaos and brings clarity to thought and form. Trill, god of Life, Death, Divinity, and Dragons, whose breath kindled the soul and whose hand shaped mortality and rebirth. The other gods—Onigod (Arcane, Monsters, and Magic), Tellemori (Water, Earth, and the Supernatural), and Flujack (Air, Sky, and Light)—reside in their own realms but appear frequently in the Celestial Court.At the center of Heaven lies the Celestial Court, a radiant structure of luminous crystal and divine light. It is the seat of divine governance, reflection, and purpose. All that occurs in the Tapestry is reflected here.This grand chamber contains six thrones: Fionil, Trill, Onigod, Tellemori, and Flujack each have their names carved in sacred runes upon their seats. The sixth throne bears no name, a smooth stone meant for Destiny, the Angel of Fate—should he ever accept godhood. Though it is offered, he eternally refuses. Surrounding the thrones are twenty-five golden lecterns, one for each of the Angels of Heaven—those who reside in the Court and those who serve across realms.Angels are powerful celestial beings created by the gods to carry out their will. Each has a domain, and most are immortal caretakers of specific realms or forces.These angels live within Heaven and tend its halls, the Library, the Gatehall, or serve directly under Fionil and Trill: Known, Angel of Knowledge – Curator of the endless Library. Livius, Angel of Life – Judges the newly dead and grants reincarnation or rest. Willia, Angel of Will – Brings autonomy to mortal and divine will. Filla, Angel of Feelings – Gives emotion to creatures. Prai, Angel of Worship – Voice between mortals and gods. Fionil’s Angels (excluding those in other realms): Clock, Known, Willia, Filla. Trill’s Angels (excluding Lucina, Death, Drana): Livius, Prai. These angels often remain within Heaven unless summoned.These angels govern domains in Feywild, Damnation, or elsewhere in the Tapestry: Lucina, Angel of Damnation – Ruler of Damnation, Sin of Pride. Cupin, Angel of Sin (female) – Interferes with the balance of morality. Death, Angel of Passing – Guides the dead. Drana, Archangel of Dragons – Overseer of dragons and war. Ignarion, the Firefather – First dragon, not an angel but a primordial celestial. Serapth (Sera) – Daughter of Destiny, a divergent angel. Lady of Fey, Angel of Fey – Overseer of the fey courts. Plantios, Angel of Flora – Maintains the cycle of plant life. Lady Love, Angel of Affection – Encourages bonds and creation. Destiny, Archangel of Fate – Master of fate; dwells between time and space. Clock, Angel of Time – Keeps time stable within the Time Stream. Sky, Angel of Air – Governs winds and skies. Day, Angel of Light – Bringer of light since Lucina’s descent. Night, Angel of Darkness – Guardian of calm and introspection. Mr. Season, Angel of Seasons – Shapes seasonal cycles. Sandman, Angel of Slumber – Induces sleep across the realms. Poki, Angel of Monsters and Beasts – Protector of monstrous beings. Arcna, Angel of the Arcane – Regulates magical essence. Undean, Angel of the Undead – Prevents spiritual corruption. Loki, Angel of Mischief – Created for Onigod’s amusement, spreader of chaos. Tended by Known, the Angel of Knowledge, the Library holds all knowledge ever recorded. The books write themselves, updated with every action in the Tapestry. It is a place of inquiry, not worship—a sacred archive of mortal and divine truth.A sacred chamber containing the divine portals. It is here where angels and gods may traverse to other realms, and mortals—very rarely—are permitted entrance under divine judgment or invitation.Here, Livius judges the souls of the dead. If worthy, they may rest in the Heavenly Expanse—a peaceful realm of endless dreamscapes. If ready, they may request rebirth, rejoining the cycle of life with echoes of their former soul.Those who are corrupted, tormented, or judged too dangerous are sent, with regret, to Damnation.Beyond the Celestial Court lies endless Heaven, a world of beauty shaped by the souls who enter it. Each spirit creates their paradise, and when ready, returns to the Chamber of Renewal to begin again.There is no war in Heaven. The angels carry small rivalries, old grudges, and contrasting philosophies—but never conflict. Gods do not war. Their focus is on the balance of the Tapestry.In Heaven, all things serve a greater design. Change is welcome. Knowledge is treasured. Rebirth is sacred. And the gods sit not above, but within the Tapestry, as its weavers, watchers, and wardens.

item.title: Damnation
item.description: Far beneath the roots of the world lies Damnation—not merely a place, but a divine mechanism, a realm of consequence, reflection, and immutable law. It is the Spiral of Sin, where souls descend not because they are cast down, but because they choose to fall. It is often called Hell, but not in anger or hatred—it is called that in truth.Unlike the heavens, which are homes to gods and stars, Damnation is without gods. No divine power can endure its terms. Its law is older than morality. No war is fought here. The Spiral does not require defense. Every soul in Damnation faces its own reflection, and that is enough.Each Circle is formed from a single Sin—not as punishment, but as mirror. The deeper one descends, the more refined, internal, and painful the sin becomes. At the Spiral’s center lies Despair—not the worst sin, but the final one, where the soul ceases to try. Pride – The refusal to kneel; the lie that one is already perfect. Envy – Coveting without understanding; the hunger for someone else's truth. Wrath – Fire that believes itself justice. Lust – The consumption of others to feed a hollow self. Greed – The endless gathering of what can never satisfy. Gluttony – Want turned into worship. Sloth – The denial of potential through stillness. Deceit – The soul sculpted from lies, forgotten even by its maker. Despair – The belief that nothing can change, and that hope is a lie. At the highest Circle, where the Spiral begins, stands Lucina, the Angel of Damnation. She is the crown of judgment, the voice of the Spiral, and the incarnation of Pride. Not fallen, not cursed—she was made for this, by the god Trill, master of life, death, and dragons.Lucina is flawless in form, and utterly calm in presence. She does not rage, she does not punish. She reveals. When she speaks, illusions fall away. She sees souls as they are—and does not blink. Titles: The Crown of Judgment, Flame That Does Not Bow Domain: Pride, Damnation, Condemnation Symbol: A silver flame coiled around a broken crown Known For: Perfect memory; she forgets nothing and forgives only what transforms. Though forged in justice, Lucina is not cold. She adores one above all—her brother in spirit:Silent, gentle, and unknowable, the Angel of Fate walks every Circle unseen. He is not a ruler, but a witness. He watches the turning of choices, and speaks only when the weight of destiny demands it.Created by Fionil, the goddess of time, space, and mind, the Angel of Fate is the executor of her dreams. Where she shapes eternity, he threads the present into it.To Lucina, he is a little brother. She loves him without pride—perhaps the only love in her heart untouched by sin. His presence softens her, though she would never admit it. Titles: The Threadkeeper, He Who Walks Before Domain: Fate, Destiny, Pattern Symbol: A golden thread wrapped around an hourglass Known For: Speaking only when no one else dares. Where the Spiral ends—in the Ninth Circle, Despair—there walks Cupin, the Angel of Sin, servant of Onigod, goddess of arcane trickery and joyful cruelty. Cupin is paradox made flesh: an angel who tempts rather than saves, who mocks the damned not to torture—but to wake them.She moves between the Circles with laughter on her lips and mercy hidden in her riddles. She offers no escape, only understanding—the cruelest and kindest gift of all. Titles: The Smiling Chain, Laugher in the Dark Domain: Sin, Temptation, Reflection Symbol: A black glass mask, cracked at the mouth Known For: Making souls laugh at their own damnation. Cupin does not belong to Damnation, yet she belongs there perfectly. Her laughter is what remains when all hope is gone. In that laughter, sometimes, is the first flicker of change.No gods dwell in Damnation. Not even the highest, not even the cruelest. The Spiral rejects divine force. Its laws are self-contained, born of choice and consequence.But angels remain—Lucina, the Judge; Fate, the Witness; Cupin, the Mirror. They are not enemies of the gods—they are their instruments. Lucina serves Trill, god of life, death, and dragons. The Angel of Fate serves Fionil, goddess of time, space, and mind. Cupin serves Onigod, who co-created the Feywild and is goddess of arcane mischief.Yet in Damnation, no one serves power. They serve truth.Damnation is not fire. It is not torment. It is clarity without mercy.Every soul here walks the Circle it earned, and in time, may walk deeper—or rise. Nothing is fixed. Nothing is easy. Nothing is unjust.To enter Damnation is to face the truth of your own story. To leave it, you must rewrite that story yourself.

item.title: The Divine Heart of the Feywild
item.description: While the Feywild is ruled by wild magic and intense emotion, its foundation is shaped by two divine beings: the ancient dreamer Tellemori, god of earth, water, and superstition, and the radiant trickster Onigod, goddess of arcana, illusion, and mischief.These two gods are not lovers, rivals, or opposites—but rather perfect complements, like river and reflection, or root and lightning. Together, they dreamed the Feywild into being: Tellemori wove its natural soul, and Onigod filled it with wonder, color, and chaos.Though war exists in the mortal and outer realms, the gods themselves never fight. The divine are bound by ancient concord, and the Feywild is the purest result of that harmony—chaotic in form, but peaceful in purpose.Tellemori is the god of earth, water, superstition, and the old magic beneath all things. He is the stillness before a storm, the rhythm of tides, the whisper of roots beneath your feet. He does not rule with commands or fury—but with patience, presence, and inevitability.He is not cold or distant. He simply moves slowly, like stone eroding or rivers carving through mountains. Those who listen find his wisdom in lullabies, folk sayings, and the quiet between breaths.He is not a god of temples or gold, but of rings of stones, cups of spring water, and children's rhymes repeated across generations.Title: The Rootfather, Stone-Sleeper, the Dreaming DepthDomains: Earth, Water, Superstition, EnduranceSymbol: A circle of water within a circle of stoneKnown For: Unshakable peace; he sees the long path, not the immediate victory.Where Onigod skips between laughter and lightning, Tellemori simply waits, watches, and grows. And yet—he is deeply fond of her. Her unpredictability does not disturb him; it amuses him, as waves amuse the shoreline.Together, they created the Feywild not as ruler and rebel, but as co-artists. Where Onigod gave it color, Tellemori gave it shape. Where she gave whimsy, he gave memory.It is said that when she teases him, he only smiles—that slow, knowing smile of the earth that cannot be rushed.Onigod is the goddess of arcane artistry, riddles, mischief, and inspired madness. She is the spark behind every strange coincidence, every spell that reshapes the world, every joke that opens the mind. Where Tellemori built the bones of the Feywild, Onigod taught it to dance.She is adored by trickster spirits, illusionists, fey pranksters, and clever sages. Her joy is in the unexpected, and she is said to play pranks on other gods—not out of malice, but to remind them not to take eternity too seriously.Her laughter is woven into the Feywild's magic itself. Every playful trick, every strange forest rule, every mischievous bargain the fey make—it all flows from her.Title: The Laughing Veil, the Mirror-MotherDomains: Arcana, Trickery, Discovery, MysterySymbol: A smiling eye within a spiralKnown For: Speaking only in layered truths; playing tricks even on her worshipers to teach them insight.She dwells within Tellu-Mountain, not in chambers of stone, but in a shifting arcane maze that rewrites itself each day. Her presence brings starlight, songbirds, and inexplicable riddles.Four powerful angels serve or dwell among the gods of the Feywild:Angel of Tellemori and steward of order in a land of chaos. She ensures rules are obeyed, debts honored, and names remembered. She is grace, courtesy, and veiled power.Title: The Twilight QueenDomain: Emotion, Glamour, StorySymbol: A mirrored mask with open lipsTellemori’s angel of flora, growth, and inevitable renewal. His slow gaze can end an age or nurture a forest. He speaks rarely, but with the gravity of seasons.Title: The Rooted FlameDomain: Seasons, Renewal, DecaySymbol: A burning blossom cupped in leavesAngel of Onigod, and her finest piece of living mischief. Ioki is the divine clown, sage, shapeshifter, and chaos-binder. Though not Tellemori’s angel, Ioki dwells permanently in the Feywild, often seen as the heart of its trickster spirit.Their bond with the Lady of Fey is legendary: lovers, rivals, mirror-souls—no one is quite sure, least of all the two of them.Title: The Mask Between, the Laughing GlyphDomain: Trickery, Arcana, ChangeSymbol: A spiral of laughing mouths inside a magic circleTellu-Mountain: The Living Divine PalaceAt the spiritual center of the Feywild rises Tellu-Mountain, a vast, living mountain whose peak touches the edge of dreams and whose roots burrow into every realm of magic. It is home to Tellemori, Onigod, and their angelic court.It is not a fortress—it does not need walls. Its protection is harmony, mystery, and deep magic. It is a palace of paradoxes: ever-shifting, yet eternal.The Deepheart Cavern – Where Tellemori sleeps and breathes. Silence lives here.The Bloomspire – Plantios’s tower of spiraling vines, always blooming and withering.The Mirrorhall – Lady of Fey’s domain, where every reflection reveals truth and history.The Foxlight Pavilion – Ioki’s realm of light, shadow, laughter, and confusion.The Spiral Maze – Onigod’s shifting temple, where answers only come when questions are asked backward.Visitors to Tellu-Mountain must answer riddles, sing to trees, or give their names to shadows. Those who try to take from it find themselves gently unmade and remade as something new.Though war rages in mortal lands, and power shifts among kings and cults, the divine realms are held in balance. The gods do not fight; their angels do not fall. They create, nudge, inspire, and redirect.The Feywild reflects this cosmic truth: that even chaos can serve peace, and that beauty and mystery are forces as strong as fire and steel.The fey do not fight for conquest. They trick, tempt, confuse, and enchant—for such things, born of Onigod’s laughter and Tellemori’s dreaming, always teach.

item.title: The feywilds
item.description: As compiled by Archsage Maerindor of the Verdant CircleBeyond the veil of the Material World lies a realm not bound by the laws of logic or time. A place of living dream, endless twilight, and primal magic. This is the Feywild—called Elatha by the elves, The Brightlands by druids, and simply the Green World by those wise enough to speak of it in hushed tones.The Feywild is not just another plane of existence. It is the soul of the natural world, shaped by memory, emotion, and belief. Here, feelings shape the land. Music can tame beasts. And the wrong word may cost your name.The Feywild mirrors the Material Plane, but its features are exaggerated. Forests are older, skies more colorful, rivers sing, and even shadows shimmer with life. A village in the mortal realm might be echoed in the Feywild as a grove of sentient trees, or a mist-covered ruin ruled by a dreaming spirit.In the Feywild, emotion is a force as real as gravity or fire. A lover’s sorrow might cause the moon to weep rain; a child’s joy may cause flowers to bloom out of season. Powerful fey can shape the world through sheer will and feeling.Words hold power in the Feywild. Promises are binding. Lies are dangerous. To say “I will return” is to make a contract. The fey do not forgive those who break their word, whether through malice or carelessness.Time does not move predictably in the Feywild. A traveler might spend a day in its woods and return to find a century passed—or discover no time passed at all. Likewise, memory itself can warp. Mortals who stay too long may forget their past, their name, or even their purpose.Passage to the Feywild is not undertaken lightly. While powerful magic can open portals, natural crossings are far more common—and far less predictable. These Fey Crossings often appear: Where natural beauty thrives: groves, waterfalls, standing stones. At liminal times: dawn, dusk, solstices, eclipses. During moments of strong emotion: love, fear, grief. Exiting the Feywild can be much harder—some are trapped for lifetimes unless aided by a native or protected by fey magic.Ruled by Queen Titania, the Seelie Court embodies growth, passion, light, and creativity. Its fey are proud, beautiful, and often helpful—though quick to anger or offense. Values: Hospitality, honor, artistry, respect. Common Creatures: Eladrin, dryads, unicorns, satyrs, noble faeries. Warning: To disrespect a Seelie is to invite eternal scorn... or be transformed into a songbird for a hundred years. The Queen of Air and Darkness leads the Unseelie—fey of shadow, sorrow, and forgotten things. They do not claim to be evil, only true to the balance of life: decay follows growth, loss follows joy. Values: Freedom, cunning, change, retribution. Common Creatures: Hags, redcaps, boggles, shadow spirits, sorrow sprites. Warning: The Unseelie always keep their bargains. You may not like how. A rare and elusive third court said to seek balance between light and shadow. Its members are quiet stewards of fate and memory, intervening only to preserve the greater weave of destiny. Leader: The Masked One, whose name is lost. Role: Observers, arbiters, oracles. Eladrin: Elves infused with seasonal magic. Their mood and power shift with the seasons. Pixies & Sprites: Tiny winged fey known for their pranks and charm magic. Hags: Once noble fey, now corrupted by greed and bitterness. Masters of curses and deals. Dryads & Naiads: Spirits bound to trees, rivers, and natural features. Harm their home, and you risk their wrath. Archfey: Semi-divine beings of immense power—rulers, legends, and walking myths. Some grant warlocks power, others seek mortal champions. Talking Animals: Many animals here are intelligent and fey-touched. Never assume a fox is just a fox. Be respectful. Courtesy is currency. Offer gifts to those you meet—tokens, songs, poetry, or favors. Ask permission before entering a grove, plucking a flower, or drinking from a stream. Never break a promise. Don’t accept food or drink without knowing the cost. Avoid giving your true name. Names are power in the Feywild. Don’t mock the strange—what seems silly may be sacred. Memory Drift: Long stays may cause memories to fade or be altered. Time Displacement: Use a d6 to determine time passed in the Material Plane upon return. Mood Manifestation: Intense emotions may cause magic surges, environmental changes, or draw attention from local fey. Dream Influence: Dreams may carry visions from the Feywild or open portals during sleep. You were raised by fey and recently exiled or released. You made a childhood bargain you don’t remember—but the fey do. A loved one vanished into the Feywild, and you seek them. You carry a fey mark—sign of a destiny not fully your own. The Feywild is not evil. Nor is it good. It is a realm of feeling and story. Of promises, riddles, and beauty too terrible to behold. Treat it with awe, and it may reveal its wonders. Offend it, and you may become one more tale whispered around the fire.

item.title: The Rise of the Holy Knights
item.description:
as remembered by KnownI remember.Of course I do. I remember everything.
I remember the way the stars dimmed during the Age of Shadows, when the gods turned their gaze away from the world—not out of cruelty, but necessity. Even I, whose purpose is to record all that was, all that is, and all that will be, could only observe as silence fell across the divine spheres. The tapestry of time wove itself in solitude, trembling under the weight of mortal uncertainty.
It was then, in that delicate stillness, that Fiondell began to fracture.
I remember how it started—not with a roar, but a whisper. A mortal, nameless then, touched a remnant of the void left behind by Kryxis’s fall. That touch became hunger. That hunger, destruction. He took the name Blightking, and with void essence pulsing through his veins, he sought to unravel the very fabric I was meant to chronicle.He desired not conquest, but erasure.The lands twisted under his influence. Forests grew teeth. Rivers bled. Children born in his blighted realm came into the world weeping shadow. And I, in my endless halls of memory, felt the ink run thin—unable to keep pace with the unraveling threads.
But Destiny... Destiny did what I could not. He acted.
Destiny, the last born of our kind, arrived when the echoes of creation had long settled, and all things seemed already shaped. He was young by our reckoning—a flicker of newness against the backdrop of the eternal—yet there was a gravity to him, as if time bowed slightly in his presence, not out of reverence, but recognition.I remember his descent not as a blaze of glory or a clash of trumpets, but as something softer. The sky did not part. The world did not pause. He came wrapped in silence, wearing a cloak the color of old parchment, the fabric heavy with dust and meaning. His feet touched the ground with the quiet grace of inevitability. He looked like a man, yes—but only if one did not look too closely. His eyes held the weight of stars dying, of choices not yet made, and his shadow never quite matched the light around him.Mortals did not see him with their eyes. He passed them on crowded streets, through marketplaces and alleys, and they never turned. But they felt him. They always did. To walk near him was to feel something unsettled within—a itch at the back of the mind, a pressure in the chest like something long forgotten was trying to be remembered. Some said they had dreams that night—of crossroads, of turning points, of clocks with no hands ticking louder than thunder. Others woke with the knowledge they needed to speak to a stranger, quit a job, leave a lover, or walk a different road entirely. None could explain why. All they knew was that the feeling would not be denied.
Destiny did not come bearing a sword. He did not smite tyrants or command storms. His was not the intervention of fire and fury, but of gentle correction. A nudge. A whispered suggestion. The placing of a single stone on a path that would lead, in time, to a mountain’s collapse.
He was not alone in his work. Prai—the eldest voice—still moved through the dreamscapes of the faithful, brushing against their sleep with the feather-light touch of prophecy. Though her body remained distant, her essence was ever present. Where Destiny laid down the thread, Prai taught hearts how to follow it. Between them, a plan began to form—not rigid, but flowing. Not declared, but sung in a melody only a few could hear. A plan like Fionil’s constellations: intricate, delicate, precise—a thing of quiet beauty and boundless meaning, visible only when you stepped far enough back.And I—I who was forbidden to touch, to speak, to alter—I watched. I observed from the spaces between time, where all things unfold both at once and not at all. I watched as they began their work. I recorded each moment, each choice, each soul turned ever so slightly toward the light or the dark. I marveled as mortals shifted not from command or threat, but from the subtle pull of purpose.They were not born into greatness.No coronation marked their rise, no divine proclamation split the heavens. There were no flames dancing across their foreheads, no halos etched in light. They came from quiet places, forgotten corners of the world. A scholar who couldn’t steady his hands when he prayed. A farmer whose fingers were more familiar with soil than scripture. A soldier who had stopped believing in heroes because he had buried too many.
And yet—Destiny found them.Not with fanfare, but with stillness. He came to them in moments of solitude, when the world fell away and only doubt remained. He did not demand their service. He simply stood beside them. Sometimes, he said nothing at all. Other times, he asked a single question, the kind that clung to the ribs and echoed for years: “What if it could be different?”
Prai’s voice drifted in silence, not like thunder, but like memory. She came not in visions but in feelings—the sense that someone was listening when they prayed into the dark. Her presence warmed cold nights and turned fear into the first step forward. She whispered not of miracles, but of responsibility. The gods, she said, had not abandoned the world.They were trusting it.And so, one by one, they changed.
Not all at once. Not cleanly. They wrestled with doubt. Some resisted. Some ran. But eventually, each turned—slowly, painfully—toward something greater than themselves. I watched as faith, long dormant in their hearts, kindled into action. I saw fear—raw, honest fear—twist and reshape itself into resolve so sharp it could cut through despair. Their souls began to glow in The tapestry of fate, not with the blinding purity of angels, but with the fierce gold of mortals who chose to stand.It was beautiful. And it hurt to witness.They found relics—not handed to them, not bestowed, but discovered, unearthed as if drawn to them by fate itself: The Lightbound Blade, a weapon that sang in sunlight, its edge humming with ancient radiance. It did not shine in the dark—it called the light to return. The Mantle of Aegis, not armor but a cloak, soft and warm. It did not repel darkness with force—it shielded like a mother’s arms, like a memory of safety no horror could touch. The Hourglass of Eternity, deceptively small, worn as a single earring. Yet within it, time whispered—not loudly, but persistently. It could not change fate, but it could make one pause, breathe, and choose.
The Tear of Trill, not a jewel but a living memory, soft with sorrow. It pulsed with a quiet glow, and when it touched wounds—of flesh or spirit—it did not merely heal. It understood. It mourned with the wounded.
The Ember of Onigod, a smoldering fragment of divine flame. It was not controlled—it judged. It did not burn with rage, but with clarity, arcane and alive. To hold it was to be seen, and found either worthy… or ash. With these relics, they stepped into purpose.They took no thrones. Wore no crowns. They did not declare themselves saints or saviors. Instead, they named themselves what they were—Knights.Not knights of empire. Not knights of creed.Knights of intention.Bound not by doctrine or allegiance, but by an oath whispered in the quiet: to hold fast, to carry the light, to stand when others fall.And so, the world gained five champions—not flawless, but faithful. Not born holy, but made holy through choice.And I, who watched, could not look away.And then came the proving.It is easy to speak of courage in the quiet. Easy to wear conviction like armor when the sun still shines. But it is only in the dark—true, unrelenting dark—that a soul is known.
And so, they were sent—not by command, but by necessity—into the hollow places of the world, the wounds of existence where even memory dared not linger. Destiny did not lead them there by hand. He merely opened the door. Prai did not shield them. She whispered that she believed they would return.Some never did.But those who did… returned changed.I remember Ser Altharion.
He was not tall, nor loud, nor the kind of man one might carve into statues. But his shadow, ah… it walked ahead of him. It whispered of duty older than stone and burden heavier than steel. He descended alone into the forgotten catacombs of the underworld, where Kryxis the Silent had once gnawed at the walls of sanity. The air was thick with voices—his own doubts, echoing back at him in the voice of the dead.He did not fight them. He listened. He named each fear. Not to defeat them, but to understand them. And in that quiet surrender, he found the Lightbound Blade. It did not blaze to life in triumph. It glowed—softly, like dawn after a long, cold night.And Lady Valeria…
The tapestry still remembers her name like a tear clinging to its threads. She had once been whole—loved, noble, full of promise. But grief had hollowed her. When she entered the forest, it was not with pride, but resignation. The trees of the Heartwood Veil were no longer trees, twisted now by the creeping rot of forgotten gods. They cried her name—not to summon her, but to curse her. They showed her every failure, every loved one she could not save.She did not scream back.She wept for them.
She held their pain like her own. And when she knelt beneath the oldest tree and laid her sorrow bare, the bark split—and from within it emerged the Tear of Trill, glowing like a second heartbeat. Not a weapon. Not a shield. A promise that wounds could mend… if someone was willing to carry them.There were others.
A thousand stories, some lost, some too sacred to repeat. A farmer who faced a storm not of wind, but time, and emerged bearing the Hourglass of Eternity. A deserter who climbed the burning spires of a city devoured by arcane fire, only to be judged and accepted by the Ember of Onigod. A mother who shielded her dying child from the void with her own body, and was wrapped in the Mantle of Aegis the moment her breath gave out—and returned with her child still sleeping in her arms.I watched them all reach the very edge of what a mortal can endure.And I recorded the moment they stepped beyond it.You ask me how they changed?They did not become invincible.They still bled. Still wept. Still feared.But they had stood before the Abyss—not as gods, but as mortals who chose to stand when nothing compelled them to.And that choice, again and again, is what made them more.Not because they could not die.But because they were willing to—if it meant others could live.It came at last. The Final Thread. The moment every whisper of prophecy had warned of, every tremble in the weave had hinted at. The battle not of gods—but of a world gasping for its breath.The Blightking, once a name, now a force, rose over the horizon like a second moon—bloated, pulsing, leaking void from wounds the world had forgotten to close. His shadow fell across nations. His voice turned rivers black. His army was not of men, but of the undone—things stripped of name and will and woven only of ruin.The skies groaned, rupturing under the pressure of what he had become. The land buckled, split, screamed.And mortals… they despaired.They knelt in dirt that bled. Held children too still. Clutched relics and old names, praying to gods who no longer answered. It was not that the divine had turned away. It was that they had given all they could.But then…Light.Not from the heavens. Not from some forgotten altar. But from within the dust, where hope had died.The Holy Knights rose—not in chariots of gold, not with wings of fire, but in silence, grit, and grace. They stood where armies had broken. They walked through the ash as though they remembered what the sky once looked like. They bore no crowns. Only scars. But when they stepped forward, even the stars seemed to pause.It was not divinity that marked them.It was determination.I remember the sound before I remember the light. The clash of relic meeting rot. The cry of a soul refusing to vanish.Ser Altharion moved through the battle like a prayer made blade. His sword, the Lightbound, did not scream with fury—it sang with clarity, slicing through the darkness with the elegance of truth. Each swing a sunrise. Each step a hymn. And when he faltered, others followed where he had carved the path.Lady Valeria was the storm’s quiet eye.
She knelt among the fallen, hands trembling but never still. She wept for each dying breath—but she did not break. The Tear of Trill shimmered against her heart as she closed wounds faster than they could reopen, giving just enough strength for others to rise and fight again.The Mantle of Aegis moved like living silver. It wrapped around crumbling ramparts, caught falling stones, turned back the void’s grasp like a mother shielding her child. Where it spread, people remembered how to stand.
The Ember of Onigod burned like a second sun. It hissed with the fury of every injustice ever endured. Its bearer left trails of glass behind him, the ground too scorched to hold its fury. He fought not with rage—but judgment. As if the world had wronged itself, and he had come to pass sentence.But make no mistake.They suffered.Oh, how they suffered.There is no tale of glory that is free of grief. No light that burns without feeding on pain.
I wrote their names, one after another, into my great ledger. My ink blurred with tears I will never admit to. For every Knight who stood, three more fell. Some vanished beneath waves of rot, screaming until even The tapestry could no longer trace their voices. Some died with a smile, knowing they had done enough. Others whispered prayers to Prai even as their lungs collapsed.Not all victories wear the shape of triumph. Some wear the shape of sacrifice.But still, they fought. And still, they fell. And through their falling… we endured.
Fiondell endured.And then… he appeared.
Destiny.Not as angel, not as god. Not cloaked in fire or fury. He arrived with the quiet weight of inevitability—like dusk at the end of a long day. No trumpets. No light from the heavens. Just the faint hush that passes over a crowd when they all feel, in their bones, that something final has come.He walked through the ruin without stirring dust. The void did not reach for him. It knew him.His presence was not power. It was certainty.He did not command. He revealed.
With voice like distant thunder behind fog, he whispered a truth only The tapestry had dared to weave:
The Blightking’s soul—twisted, swollen, hollowed by void—was bound not just to this world, but to something beneath it. Kryxis. The eternal knot of corruption. The wound that never healed. To destroy the Blightking meant more than ending a tyrant.It meant severing a soul from the source of all decay.The ritual required was old. Older than words. Older than the angels. I should know—I was there when it was first whispered.But such things always demand a cost. A life willing to be unmade. Not consumed. Not killed. But given—entirely, freely, without hesitation.And Ser Altharion…Altharion did not hesitate.He stepped forward before anyone else could breathe a protest. His armor cracked, stained, his shoulders slumped not from weakness but weight. He looked not like a hero, but like a man who had been one long enough.He smiled.Not because he welcomed death.But because he had already died… —in every village he left to defend another, —in every friend he buried, —in every piece of himself he gave away to keep the light burning.This wasn’t martyrdom. It was completion. His life had been a gift. And now, he gave it back.The ritual began.Lady Valeria, still bloodied, still kneeling by the wounded, collapsed to her knees. Her cries were raw, wordless, too mortal for the moment. She tried to stop him, even knowing she could not. And I—wept too. My quill trembled. I who never forget, wished in that moment that I could.The relics responded.One by one, as if remembering their purpose. They rose—not from the ground, but from within. Each hummed with what remained of the gods’ will, but it was Altharion’s soul that bound them together.He became not a man. Not a knight. Not even a weapon.He became a will. Sharp. Brilliant. Unstoppable.Light without shadow.He surged skyward, drawn not by gravity but by purpose. The void tried to recoil, but it was far too late. The Blightking turned—slow, confused, almost human in that final instant.And then…Altharion struck.Not with fire. Not with fury. But with clarity.Straight through the Blightking’s heart. The world held its breath.And the void…Screamed.It was not the scream of a beast or tyrant. It was the scream of undoing. Of something ancient being unwritten. The sky shattered again—but this time, the stars poured through.
The tapestry strained, rippled—then stilled.And then…Peace.Not silence. Peace. The kind that settles only after everything has been broken and yet, somehow, held together anyway.The kind you don’t earn with power. Only with sacrifice.When the dust settled, it wasn’t just the land that breathed again.
The world itself—Fiondell—exhaled, as if it had been holding its breath for centuries. The earth trembled in a final shudder, and then, with a grace that defied the destruction that had come before, it repaired itself. The void, once so consuming, slithered back into the corners from which it had emerged. Hissing like a wound denied its infection.Life returned.The trees, once charred and twisted by the void, stretched tall once more. The rivers, once thick with poison, now ran clear, shimmering with the brightness of renewal. And in every corner of the world, children were born whole. Born without the scars of the past. Without the weight of the Blightking’s shadow.Yet, the Knights—the ones who survived—were never the same. They had stood at the edge of the abyss, and now they had to live with the memory of what they had done. What they had sacrificed. What they had become.Ser Altharion was gone. His sacrifice had closed the rift. But in his absence, something lingered. A feeling no mortal could ever truly shed. They had become something more than mortal, but in that transformation, they had also become something less—less certain of their place in the world. More aware of the fragility of it all.
Their eyes—once full of hope, now held galaxies of sorrow. They no longer saw the world with the clear sight of those untouched by tragedy. They saw everything. Every ripple in The tapestry. Every tear in the fabric of fate.Their hands, trembling not from fear, but from the weight of memory—of what they had seen the gods do through them. Of what they had seen themselves become.They had felt the touch of divinity—yes—but it had not been a divine touch that made them holy. No, it was their own choices. Their willingness to sacrifice—not just their lives, but their humanity—that made them more than mortal. And they felt it, with every step they took.Some of the knights wandered. Their hearts too heavy for peace. Too fractured to rest. They roamed, seeking what they had lost in the fires of battle—hope, purpose, meaning. And some, they never found it. They drifted, mere whispers in the wind. Their names fading into the dust they had once conquered.But not all were lost.Others, like Lady Valeria, turned inward. They built, not temples for themselves, but for something greater. They built temples to unity. To sacrifice. To the delicate, holy dance that existed between the mortal and the divine.Lady Valeria never took a title. Not once did she seek praise or adulation. She never needed it. She had already been made more than any title could proclaim. Instead, she walked. Quietly. With grace. With a purpose that was hers alone. But wherever she went—wherever her steps echoed—people spoke of how their dreams grew brighter. How their hearts grew lighter.
And though they never saw her cry—Known saw it. I saw her face, streaked with the weight of everything she had carried. But I also saw the glow in her eyes. The quiet peace that she had found, even in the wake of such devastation.
Destiny and Prai—the two who had woven it all together—returned to the veiled planes. Their task, for now, was done. They did not linger in the mortal world, for their hands were never meant to stay there forever. But before they left, they looked upon the world they had shaped, and for the first time, I saw something akin to satisfaction in their gaze. It was not pride. Not joy. But something deeper. Fulfillment.And me?
I, Known, stood at the edge of the world, watching as all of this played out. I recorded. I documented. But not in ink. No, this was not mere memory. This was emotion. Every moment was etched into the Library—not with quill, but with the pulse of my own heart. I wrote the pages, but they were not mine to hold. Not only mine.Because when I read these pages again, I do not just remember. I feel.I feel the weight of Altharion’s sacrifice. I feel the grief in Valeria’s eyes. I feel the love and the loss of each knight, each soul who had answered the call.And when I do, I am reminded that knowledge is not just memory. It is not just what we recall. It is meaning. It is what we have learned, and what we have been made to feel.Thus, let all who read this know— The Holy Knights did not rise because the gods commanded it. They rose because they listened.
They heard the quiet voice of Destiny, and they answered—not with hesitation, but with thunder.
For a moment—just one fleeting moment—The tapestry sang. And that song, woven of mortal flesh and divine will, will echo forever.
— Known, Angel of Knowledge Inscribe of All Threads, Witness to the Turning Ages

item.title: The Choice of Destiny
item.description: As remembered by Destiny, the Angel of FateI remember that day clearly—though for me, clarity is not rare. Time is not a river I am swept along but an ocean I walk upon. The past and future hold no secrets. Still, this moment… it lingers. It echoes.The Celestial Tapestry stretched before me like a breathing universe. Threads of silver, gold, and crimson shimmered in every direction, each one humming softly with the choices of mortals below. Every soul, every step, every breath—it all lived here, in this place between what is and what could be. And I—Destiny—I was the caretaker of that vast, fragile beauty.I walked among the threads as one walks through a garden. My robe, woven from shadows and stars, whispered with each step. Feathers drifted from my wings, slow as falling snow, vanishing before they could touch the fabric of fate. Around me, time ticked in soft rhythm—never louder than a whisper, never faster than a breath.I had just guided a merchant away from an untimely ambush. Only a nudge, just enough to tilt his path toward a narrow bridge and away from a waiting dagger. He would never know. He would simply wonder why he chose the left path. That was enough."A gentle nudge," I whispered to myself. That is all I allow. That is all I must ever allow.And then, silence. Not the stillness I cherish, but the hollow quiet that follows an earthquake in the soul.They appeared—all five. The gods. My creators, my judges, my kin in spirit if not in form: Flujack, Tellemori, Fionil, Onigod, and Trill. Their arrival cracked the rhythm of this place. The threads shivered under their gaze. Even time itself hesitated.I turned. Slowly. Always slowly.“You usually send Prai,” I said, keeping my voice still, my hands folded neatly behind me. “Has something changed?”“Yes,” said Trill. Warm, patient, like the scent of summer. “Something within you.”I said nothing. I waited. Waiting is what I do best.Fionil, my maker, stepped forward. Her eyes—oh, her eyes—carried the weight of eternity. She had sculpted me from purpose and time, breathed into me the quiet hunger to guide without ruling. “You have exceeded even my expectations,” she said. “You have preserved the balance through storms of chaos, and never asked for more. It is time.”“Time,” murmured Tellemori, voice like stone. “For you to ascend.”Flujack smiled. His joy, too bright for most eyes, did not reach mine. “Imagine it, Destiny. You would not guide fate anymore. You would write it. Make your own threads. No more limits. No more ‘nudges.’”Onigod, wild and sharp as broken glass in moonlight, tilted her head at me. “You’ve danced with catastrophe and never stumbled. You see mortals clearer than we do. You care more than most gods ever could. That’s why this offer is real.”They meant it. Each of them. The gods don’t offer divinity lightly.And still, I was quiet.I turned back to the Tapestry. I reached down—there, a child’s thread. Thin. Trembling. Unseen by any mortal, yet in her lay a destiny vast enough to ripple through a thousand lives. She would become a healer. She would save the boy who would save the woman who would defy the tyrant. A cascade of quiet miracles. All beginning here.I shifted her thread gently. Just enough to guide her path toward her future mentor.That’s all.Then I looked at the gods.“Do you know why I don’t pull the threads tighter?” I asked, softly. “Why I don’t sculpt lives like marble?”They said nothing.“Because if I do, they aren’t lives anymore. They’re statues. Beautiful, maybe—but frozen. Trapped. No growth. No sorrow. No hope.”I stepped toward them, the sound of ticking echoing behind my words.“I guide. I don’t command. Free will wasn’t a mistake. It was the first gift. And I—I exist to protect it. If I become a god, I will lose that. I’ll lose myself.”Fionil looked at me—not with disappointment, but with pride. And that made it harder.“Then you choose to stay,” she said.“I choose to serve,” I corrected gently. “Not with temples, not with sermons. Just with... nudges. Quiet ones.”There was silence among them.Then Onigod, ever the storm in flesh, laughed—a bright, reckless sound. “Well said, shadowbird. We’ll not chain you with a crown.”Trill stepped closer and laid a hand on my shoulder. His grip was warm. “If ever you change your mind, the offer remains.”“I will not.”Flujack’s light dimmed slightly, though he gave a nod. “You’re certain. I respect that.”And just like that, they faded.Stone to silence. Flame to flicker. Light to shadow. And finally—Fionil. She lingered.She stepped near and touched my face, her hand colder than starlight and softer than wind. “I am proud,” she said, so quietly it brushed my soul more than my ears. “You remember why we made you.”“I have never forgotten.”And then she, too, was gone.The silence that followed was not empty. It was full.Full of the Tapestry. Full of the ticking. Full of the living, breathing, hoping world.I stood for a long while. I don’t know how long. Time, after all, is not my master. It is my canvas.Eventually, I returned to my threads.There—a young woman, uncertain, afraid of change. A shepherdess. Her path forked, her spirit trembled.“Let me help you decide,” I whispered.Just a nudge.In the village below, she turned right instead of left. That single step would lead her to meet a knight on the road. Years from now, they would stand side by side before a fire-lit crowd, telling stories of kindness and quiet valor.She would never know I was there.That is the point.No crown. No throne. No praise.Only this.The threads.And me.And always… love.
